prompt: What is (are) Skin Cancer ?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Your skin is the largest organ of your body. It protects you from heat, sunlight, injury, and infection. But skin conditions, including skin cancer, affect millions of Americans.    Cancer is the growth of abnormal cells. They grow in an uncontrolled way and can invade nearby tissues. In skin cancer, this growth affects the skin. While there are different types, most skin cancers are either         - Basal cell carcinoma, which develops in the lowest layer of the skin     - Squamous cell carcinoma, which develops in the top layer of the skin        A common type of growth called a mole can also develop on sun-exposed skin. Moles are almost always benign, which means they're not cancer. If a mole becomes cancerous, it is called melanoma. Melanoma is the most serious type of skin cancer.    Skin cancer is the most common of all cancers. One of the biggest risk factors for developing skin cancer is exposure to ultraviolet light from sunlight. Wearing sunscreen and protective clothing can help reduce your risk.    NIH: National Cancer Institute","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Cancer cells in the skin grow out of control. Skin cancer is the most common form of cancer in the United States. The two most common types of skin cancer are basal cell carcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma. Another form is called melanoma, which is much less common, but more dangerous. Anyone can develop skin cancer, but risk goes up if you are white, spend time in the sun, or have a family history of skin cancer.     Skin cancers almost always develop on skin exposed to the sun. The first sign is usually a new growth or a sore that does not heal. The treatment of skin cancer depends on the type of cancer and how far it has spread. Some local treatment options are surgery, cryotherapy, photodynamic therapy, and radiation therapy for advanced cases.    NIH: National Cancer Institute","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Your skin is the largest organ in your body. It keeps germs from invading your body, and it keeps you from losing the water your body needs. It also helps regulate your body temperature, stores vitamins and minerals, and produces vitamin D.     Skin cancer is the abnormal growth of skin cells. It most often develops on skin exposed to the sun's ultraviolet (UV) radiation. But it may also occur on areas of the body not normally exposed to sunlight.     The most common types of skin cancers are basal cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and melanoma.      - Basal cell carcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma are the most common. They are related to sun exposure, and they are usually found on the head, neck, hands, and arms. They rarely spread to other parts of the body.    - Melanoma is the most serious kind of skin cancer. It is also related to exposure to UV radiation from the sun and tanning beds. You should check your skin regularly for new or unusual growths, or changes in the size or appearance of existing moles.    Skin cancer is most common in older men, but all people need to be careful when they are in the sun. If you blister or turn red, you are getting too much sun. Early diagnosis and treatment are important because they reduce the risk of the cancer spreading.    NIH: National Cancer Institute","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"If you keep up with the news, you know that many people these days are diagnosed with skin cancer. Skin cancer is the most common type of cancer in the United States. It is also one of the most preventable. If you protect your skin from the sun and use sunscreen, you can lower your risk.    Despite the fact that there are many of us, there are really only two main types of people. Those who burn easily and those who tan easily. If you burn more than you tan, you have a higher risk of getting skin cancer.    If you do get skin cancer, the most common type is basal cell carcinoma. It is very treatable and rarely spreads. Melanoma is the most serious type of skin cancer. Melanoma forms in the melanocytes, the cells that make pigment and give skin its natural color. Sun exposure causes it. Once it has spread throughout the body, melanoma is very hard to treat.    NIH: National Cancer Institute","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Everyone's skin has millions of small cells. The skin is the body's largest organ, and it protects you from heat, sunlight, injury, and infection. Skin cancer is the abnormal growth of skin cells. It most often develops on skin exposed to the sun. But it can also occur on areas of the body not normally exposed to sunlight.     There are three major types of skin cancer:       - Basal cell carcinoma - These are slow-growing cancers that appear as a flesh-colored, pearl-like bump or a pinkish patch of skin.     - Squamous cell carcinoma - These are more serious and may appear as crusted or scaly red patches, open sores, or warts. They can become disfiguring if not treated.     - Melanoma - This is the most serious type. It may develop in an existing mole or suddenly appear as a new dark spot on the skin.       Skin cancers are common. Skin cancer is one of the most common cancers in the United States.    Basal cell and squamous cell skin cancers are more common, but much less serious than melanoma skin cancer. They are far more common among older white men.    Almost all skin cancers are caused by too much exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation from the sun. Treatments include removing the tumor and therapies such as radiation, heat, or drugs. Treatment of most basal cell and squamous cell skin cancers can be successful if they are found early.     National Cancer Institute","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What is (are) Plasma Cell Neoplasms (Including Multiple Myeloma) ?
completions:
{"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Key Points
                    - Plasma cell neoplasms are diseases that affect plasma cells, a type of white blood cell.     - In multiple myeloma, abnormal plasma cells build up in the bone marrow and form tumors in many bones of the body.    - Certain diseases and conditions affect plasma cells and are not cancer.
                
                
                    Plasma cell neoplasms are diseases that affect plasma cells, a type of white blood cell.
                    Plasma cells help protect the body from infection. They do this by producing antibodies that recognize and attach to germs and to abnormal cells, which helps destroy them. All plasma cells develop from the same plasma cell (cell clone). If one plasma cell grows out of control, it can cause different disorders.
                
                
                    In multiple myeloma, abnormal plasma cells build up in the bone marrow and form tumors in many bones of the body.
                    In multiple myeloma, one plasma cell clone develops in the bone marrow and becomes cancer. Cancer plasma cells, myeloma cells, replace healthy white blood cells in the bone marrow and make a tumor. The tumor may weaken bones and cause them to break easily. Myeloma cells also make an abnormal antibody, called monoclonal (M) protein. A high level of M protein can cause kidney problems and crowd out healthy antibodies. This lowers the body's ability to fight infection.   See the following PDQ summaries for more information about treating multiple myeloma:          - Adult Acute Myeloid Leukemia Treatment     - Childhood Acute Myeloid Leukemia Treatment     - Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia Treatment     - Myelodysplastic Syndromes / Myelodysplastic Syndromes - Myelodysplastic/Myeloproliferative Neoplasms    - Waldenstrom Macroglobulinemia Treatment
                
				                
                    Certain diseases and conditions affect plasma cells and are not cancer.
                    Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) is a common condition in older people. A small amount of M protein is made by plasma cells in the bone marrow but there are no other signs of multiple myeloma. MGUS does not usually cause problems and is often found by chance during a blood test. Certain levels of M protein in the blood or another level of protein in the urine can help diagnose MGUS. Treatment is not usually necessary for MGUS, but it can be a precursor to cancer and patients will usually have regular checkups to watch for signs they may have cancer.    Solitary plasmacytoma is a tumor formed by one small group of plasma cells that have become cancer. It can be either a solitary plasmacytoma of bone, which forms in the bone, or an extramedullary plasmacytoma, which forms in tissue other than bone. It is not known what causes a solitary plasmacytoma to form. Plasmacytomas can sometimes develop into multiple myeloma. Treatment for solitary plasmacytoma is usually radiation therapy. If you are diagnosed with solitary plasmacytoma of bone, another bone tumor may form, or you may develop signs, symptoms, and treatment needs like those for multiple myeloma. For this reason, regular follow-up tests are important.   See the following PDQ summaries for more information:         - Adult Hodgkin Lymphoma Treatment     - Adult Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma Treatment","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.     Dendritic cell vaccine therapy     Dendritic cell vaccine therapy is a type of biologic therapy. Biologic therapy is a cancer treatment that uses the patient's immune system to fight cancer. Biologic therapy is also called biotherapy or immunotherapy. Dendritic cell vaccine therapy uses dendritic cells (a type of immune system cell) to make a vaccine. The dendritic cells recognize a cancer cell and help the body build an active, long-lasting immune response against cancer cells. They do this by targeting a specific protein on a given cancer cell called a "tumor antigen." Once the dendritic cells are in the body, they make more of the patient's immune system cells to attack the cancer cells that have that tumor antigen on them. This helps the body attack the cancer and keep it from coming back.

Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.   Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future. Signs or symptoms may be caused by the tumor mass or may be from the cancer spreading to other parts of the body.   The following signs and symptoms are more common in children with neuroblastoma than in children without neuroblastoma:         - A lump in the abdomen, legs, or feet.    - Pain from tumor growth.    - Swelling in the stomach or around the belly button.    -  Fever.    -  Diarrhea.    -  Bone pain. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Most neuroblastomas occur in children with no family history of the disease, and a genetic cause for the neuroblastoma is found in about 1% of all cases. Neuroblastoma that is linked to an inherited mutation usually occurs as part of familial neuroblastoma syndrome, a condition that causes more than one case of neuroblastoma within a family.  Mutations in the PHOX2B and ALK genes have been associated with neuroblastoma.  Most neuroblastomas caused by a genetic mutation are associated with a change in the PHOX2B gene, which provides instructions for making a protein that helps form nerve cells, particularly nerve cells involved in involuntary actions such as breathing and digesting food.  In familial neuroblastoma syndrome, an alteration in the ALK gene causes an altered ALK protein that is active when it is not supposed to be. The altered ALK protein signals nerves cells to divide repeatedly, potentially leading to the formation of neuroblastomas in certain people with the altered gene. It is unclear why some children with an ALK mutation develop neuroblastoma and others do not; some other factor, such as a tumor suppressor gene or an environmental exposure, may be involved.  Recently, neuroblastoma that is not matched to a known syndrome (non-syndromic neuroblastoma) has been linked to a number of additional genes; however, a direct cause-and-effect relationship has not been established in most cases.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Just 1% to 2% of neuroblastoma cases result from an inherited gene mutation. In these cases, the inherited mutation can be passed from parent to child, typically in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to increase the risk of neuroblastoma. {"finish_reason":"length","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Key Points
                    - After neuroblastoma has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the primary tumor or to other parts of the body.     - There are 6 stages of neuroblastoma: stage 1, stage 2A, stage 2B, stage 3, stage 4, and stage 4S.    - The treatment of neuroblastoma is based on the stage of the cancer and risk group.
                
                
                    After neuroblastoma has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the primary tumor or to other parts of the body.
                    The process used to find out if cancer has spread within the primary tumor or to other parts of the body is called staging. Staging neuroblastoma has been difficult because different doctors used different staging systems. In 2005, neuroblastoma specialists around the world agreed on an international staging system (the International Neuroblastoma Risk Group Staging System, or INRGSS) that would be used when treating patients. The new system is based on whether the tumor has spread and can be removed by surgery, and whether there are certain image-defined risk factors (IDRFs). There are 4 stages: stage L1, stage L2, stage M, and stage MS.   Tests and procedures to determine the stage of the cancer include the following:         -   Biopsy : The removal of cells or tissues so they can be viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer. For example, if there is a tumor in the abdomen and it cannot be removed completely during surgery, a biopsy may be done.   -   X-ray : An x-ray is a way to create a picture of the internal organs. An x-ray of the chest may be done to check for signs that cancer has spread.     -   CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the chest, abdomen, or pelvis, taken from different angles. The pictures are made by a computer linked to an x-ray machine. A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly. This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography. A CT scan of the chest and/or abdomen may be done.     -   MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the chest, abdomen, or pelvis. This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).    -   MIBG scan : A procedure used to find neuroblastoma cells. A very small amount of radioactive material is injected into a vein and travels through the bloodstream. The radioactive material is taken up by neuroblastoma cells and is detected by a scanner.    -   Bone scan : A procedure to check if there are rapidly dividing cells, such as cancer cells, in the bone. The parathyroid glands are not the same as the thyroid gland, and the diseases of the parathyroid glands are different from disorders of the thyroid. Sometimes there may be 5 to 8 parathyroid glands, or fewer than 4.   Parathyroid glands control the amount of calcium in the blood and bones and release parathyroid hormone through the blood. Bone cells have receptors for this hormone. The hormone tells the bone cells to release calcium from the bones into the blood when the level of calcium in the blood is too low. The hormone also tells the kidneys to release calcium into the urine (pee), tell the intestines to take calcium from food, and tell the bones to take calcium from the blood.     Hyperparathyroidism is a disorder caused by increased levels of parathyroid hormone in the blood. It is usually caused by a parathyroid adenoma (a parathyroid tumor that is not cancer) but can also be caused by parathyroid cancer. When there is too much parathyroid hormone, too much calcium is released from the bones into the blood and the bones have less calcium than they need. Too much calcium is also released by the kidneys into the urine and taken from the intestines. High levels of calcium in the blood may cause kidney stones. Parathyroid cancer is the cause of about 1 percent of all cases of hyperparathyroidism. This summary is about parathyroid cancer.                     The penis is part of a man's reproductive system. It is made up of a mass of muscle and other tissues covered by skin. During sexual arousal, the muscles of the penis relax, allowing blood to flow in and fill two chambers (the corpora cavernosa). This blood flow causes the penis to become larger and stiff (erect). At the end of the penis is a layer of tissue called the glans. The foreskin is a loose layer of skin that covers and protects the glans. The opening of the urethra, the tube that carries urine and semen out of the body, is at the tip of the glans.      Cancer that forms in the penis most often forms in skin cells, but may also form in connective tissues and lymph nodes. Cancer can also spread to the penis from other parts of the body. Cancer that is formed in another part of the body and spreads to the penis is called secondary cancer of the penis.

                    Prostate cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the prostate.

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Cancer survivorship has become a part of cancer care for all ages. Multiple national groups, including the National Cancer Institute's Office of Cancer Survivorship and LiveStrong, address issues associated with the aftermath of a diagnosis of cancer. The goal of the cancer survivorship movement is to provide better coordination of cancer care, help survivors with problems that are usually seen late in cancer, support research, and provide education. \"Cancer survivorship\" is defined within this framework as the period from diagnosis until the end of life, no matter how long a person survives.    A prostate cancer prognosis is the likely outcome or course of the disease; it is the chance of recovery or recurrence. Prostate cancer prognosis depends on the following:         - How fast the cancer is growing.    - Whether the cancer has spread to other parts of the body.    - How the cancer responds to treatment.    - Whether the cancer recurs (comes back) after treatment. Treatment of prostate cancer may be delayed in some men, especially if the cancer caused no symptoms at the time of diagnosis and was found by chance during a biopsy. Treatment can begin if there are signs the cancer is getting worse. Another reason treatment of slow-growing prostate cancer can be delayed for some men is a concern about the possible side effects of the treatment. Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial. Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.

There are different types of radical prostatectomy:                   -  Perineal prostatectomy is removal of the prostate through an incision (cut) in the perineum, the area between the scrotum and anus.      -  Retropubic prostatectomy is removal of the prostate through an incision in the lower abdomen. This type of surgery may be done as a nerve-sparing operation, and may allow patients to regain continence and potency.       -  Robotic-assisted laparoscopic prostatectomy: Surgery to remove the prostate using a laparoscope (a thin video camera) inserted through small incisions in the abdomen. Instruments are used to perform the surgery. The patient's position at a slight tilt allows the intestines to move to one side while the instrument arm of the robot moves around the patient on an arc. The tilt also improves the view for the surgeon.     -  Transurethral resection of the prostate: A surgical procedure used to relieve symptoms caused by prostate cancer, such as difficulty urinating. It is most often used when the patient is not able to have surgery to remove the entire tumor. A resectoscope (a thin, lighted tube with a wire loop on the end) is inserted through the tip of the penis into the urethra. The wire loop is used to remove prostate tissue, including any parts that are blocking urine flow through the urethra. This procedure is also used when a patient is having hormone or radiation therapy. It may help reduce side effects of these therapies or complications from the prostate continuing to grow during therapy. There are two types of radiation therapy:            -  External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer. With SBRT, the radiation is usually given in fewer fractions than standard radiation therapy.       -  Three-dimensional (3-D) conformal radiation therapy: A type of external radiation therapy that uses a computer to make a 3-dimensional picture of the inside of the body and is used to deliver a radiation dose that is shaped to fit the tumor.       -  Intensity-modulated radiation therapy (IMRT): A type of 3-dimensional radiation therapy that uses a computer to adjust the radiation dose received by healthy tissue and the tumor.       -  Proton beam radiation therapy:  A type of high-energy, external radiation therapy that uses streams of protons (small positively charged particles of matter) to make radiation.                     A risk factor is anything that affects your chance of getting a disease.
                    Risk factors can increase your chance of getting a disease. Almost by definition, the cause of a disease is a risk factor for that disease. Different diseases have different risk factors. For example, exposure to sunlight is a risk factor for skin cancer. In contrast, sunlight is not a risk factor for other types of cancer.                     Prostate cancer has several risk factors.
                    Studies have found several risk factors for prostate cancer. Some of these, such as age and family history, can not be changed. Others, such as diet, could be changed. Research is ongoing to learn more about the link between risk factors and prostate cancer.
                
                
                    Age
                    The risk of having prostate cancer increases greatly as a man gets older. Prostate cancer is rare in men younger than 40, but it becomes more common after age 50. The average age at the time of diagnosis is about 67 years. About 6 of 10 cases of prostate cancer are diagnosed in men older than 65.
                
                
                    Race/ethnicity
                    Prostate cancer is diagnosed more often in African American men and in Caribbean men of African ancestry than in men of other races/ethnicities. African American men also have the highest death rate from prostate cancer. Prostate cancer occurs less often in Asian American and Hispanic/Latino men than in non-Hispanic white men.
                
                
                    Family history

This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.    -  MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the chest. prompt: What is the outlook for Rectal Cancer ?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following:         - The stage of the cancer (whether it affects part of the body or has spread to other parts of the body).    - Whether the cancer cells are well-differentiated or poorly-differentiated.        - Whether the patient generally is healthy.    - Whether all of the cancer was taken out with surgery.    - Whether the cancer just came back (recurred) after treatment.    - Whether the patient has certain changes in the DNA mismatch repair genes (Lynch syndrome - see below).           Even when rectal cancer has been cured, there is a chance it will come back. Treatment of rectal cancer may damage the rectum and nearby tissues. Patients who have had treatment for rectal cancer need to be followed closely by their doctors.    Rectal cancer is stage 0, I, II, III, or IV depending on how far the cancer has spread. For stage 0 rectal cancer, there is no cancer in lymph nodes and the cancer has not spread to nearby tissue.                      If untreated, most rectal polyps will become cancerous.Rectal polyps are growths on the inside lining of the rectum. They are relatively common in adults over age 50. Regular screening is important because rectal polyps can turn into cancer and be life-threatening. However, not all polyps turn into cancer. In most patients, polyps that become cancer usually are larger than 1 centimeter (cm) and have a certain tissue pattern seen under a microscope called tubular villous or villous adenoma. Polyps can be cancer, too.   Polyps often do not cause any signs or symptoms. Doctors find most rectal polyps during screening tests for colorectal cancer. Because there is a risk that polyps return, follow-up checking (surveillance) is often needed for life.    Some rectal polyps are flat (sessile) and spread across the surface of the rectum lining, while other rectal polyps hang from the surface of the rectum by a stalk (pedunculated). A person can have one or more than one polyp at a time. If a person has more than 20 polyps, there is an increased risk that polyps will form in the rest of the colon.    Types of polyps include:            -   Adenomatous polyps: These polyps may turn into cancer and are called adenomas. Adenomatous polyps are most often removed during a sigmoidoscopy or colonoscopy.    -   Hyperplastic polyps: These polyps usually are not precancerous.    -   Inflammatory polyps: These polyps may form up to 8 years after a person has had ulcerative colitis.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

Wastes move through the large intestine and leave the body through the rectum and the anus.    The walls of the colon and rectum have several layers of tissue. Bones, lungs, and liver are the sites most often affected by metastatic colorectal cancer. The cancer cells in metastatic colorectal cancer are the same type of cells as those that were originally in the colon or rectum. Children and teens should get 1 hour (60 minutes) or more of physical activity every day, and should include strengthening exercises on at least three days a week. Regular exercise helps lower the risk of many types of cancer. Certain medicines may help lower the risk of some types of cancer. Aspirin and other non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) lower the chance of getting colon polyps and of the polyps turning into cancer.                     Cancer of the colon and rectum, also called colorectal cancer, is the second leading cause of cancer death in the United States.
                    Cancer can form in tissues of the colon and rectum. Colorectal cancer begins most often from adenomatous polyps, which are benign (not cancerous) growths that form on the inside of the colon or rectum. Over time some of these polyps can become cancer and start to grow into the wall of the colon and rectum. Usually, it takes many years for normal tissue in the colon and rectum to change into a polyp and then into cancer, which means finding and removing polyps can prevent cancer from forming. Common symptoms of colorectal cancer include blood in or on your stool, a change in bowel habits, abdominal discomfort, weakness or fatigue, and unexplained weight loss. These symptoms can be caused by other conditions but if you have symptoms you think might be from cancer, see your doctor. Treatment options for colorectal cancer depend on several factors, including the stage of the cancer. Treatment may include surgery, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy.
                
                
                    Colorectal cancer develops from a growth called a polyp.
                    The colorectal area is one of the few places in the body where doctors can look for and remove pre-cancerous growths (called polyps). Polyps can change into cancer over time. Removing polyps through a colonoscopy lowers your risk of developing colorectal cancer.
                
                
                    Genes you inherit from your parents, lifestyle, and age can affect your risk of colorectal cancer.
                    Anything that increases your chance of getting a disease is called a risk factor. Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesn't mean that you will not get cancer. Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk. Risk factors include the following:         - Being 50 or older.    - Inherited colorectal cancer syndromes that include familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) and a genetic condition called Lynch syndrome, which is also known as hereditary non-polyposis colon cancer (HNPCC).     - Having inflammatory bowel disease, including ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease.    - Having polyps in the colon or rectum.    - Having cancer in the colon, rectum, or ovary can increase the risk of colorectal cancer.    - Personal history of endometrial cancer or breast cancer with or without a family history of colorectal cancer may also be linked to an increased risk of colorectal cancer.    - African Americans have a higher rate of colorectal cancer than other groups in the United States.    - Smoking cigarettes and being overweight increase the risk of colorectal cancer.
                
                
                    Colorectal cancer usually occurs in people older than 50.
                    The risk of getting colorectal cancer rises as people get older. Most cases occur in people older than 50. Other risk factors for colorectal cancer include African American ancestry, and a personal or family history of colon cancer or certain types of polyps. People with certain bowel diseases may also be at an increased risk. Anyone, however, can get colorectal cancer.    Death rates from colorectal cancer have been declining in the United States, but the trend is less pronounced in African Americans. One reason may be differences in screening rates. To reduce the risk of colorectal cancer, all men and women who are at average risk should be regularly screened beginning at age 45. See the following PDQ summaries for information about screening for colorectal cancer and the treatment of colorectal cancer:         -  Colorectal Cancer Screening Summary     -  Adult Treatment     -  Childhood Treatment        The colorectal cancer prevention (prevention) summary has information about ways to prevent (lower the risk of getting) colorectal cancer.
				                
				                
				                    For colorectal cancer screening, the following tests may be used:
				                    A test or procedure used to find cancer in people who have no symptoms is called a screening test. The early detection and treatment of certain cancers, such as colorectal cancer, is called screening.    Most colorectal cancers start from polyps (abnormal growths in the colon or rectum) and may not cause signs or symptoms until they grow larger or there is bleeding. Screening tests may find polyps before they become cancer and can also find colorectal cancer early, when it is easier to treat.    The following tests and procedures may be used for colorectal cancer screening.     Fecal occult blood test (gFOBT or FOBT)    A test to check samples of feces (stool) for blood that cannot be seen by the naked eye. This test may be done on three samples of stool collected at home. Bleeding can be a sign of polyps or cancer. The fecal occult blood test (gFOBT) should not be confused with the fecal immunochemical test (FIT).    Fecal immunochemical test (FIT)    A test using antibodies to check for blood in the stool. This test is different than the fecal occult blood test (gFOBT).     Stool DNA test (sDNA)    A test done on a sample of stool to check for abnormal DNA from cancer or polyp cells. Sometimes stool DNA tests also check for blood in the stool.    Flexible sigmoidoscopy     A procedure in which a doctor inserts a short, thin, lighted tube into the rectum and looks at the rectum and lower third of the colon. If the doctor sees polyps or cancer, then a colonoscopy is done. A colonoscopy is like a flexible sigmoidoscopy, except that the doctor uses a longer tube to look at the rectum and entire colon. People with best disease usually develop signs and symptoms of the condition in childhood, although the condition can also be diagnosed in adulthood. Problems with vision begin with blurred vision or abnormal color perception. Over time, vision worsens, and many people become legally blind by the age of 60.  The earliest sign of best disease is an abnormal-looking area in the center of the retina called the macula. It may look like an egg yolk (\"vitelliform\" means yolk-like), a scrambled-egg-like material, or a hole in the center of the retina. The problem with vision usually develops years after the appearance of the abnormal area in the retina.  Best disease is a genetic condition caused by changes (mutations) in the BEST1 gene. Approximately 90% of people with best disease inherit the gene mutation from an affected parent; in these cases, the condition is said to be autosomal dominant. The other 10% of cases result from new (de novo) mutations in the gene; people with these cases typically have no history of the disorder in their family. Some individuals with a mutation in the BEST1 gene never develop vision problems or any other signs or symptoms of the condition.  The worldwide prevalence of best disease ranges from 1 in 5,500 (American) to 1 in 15,000 (Swedish).","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

Hemoglobin is the protein molecule in red blood cells that carries oxygen. In people with beta-thalassemia, the body doesn't make enough of a component (subunit) of hemoglobin called beta-globin, which prevents red blood cells from carrying enough oxygen. There are three clinical forms of beta-thalassemia: thalassemia minor, also called beta-thalassemia trait; thalassemia intermedia; and thalassemia major.  Thalassemia minor usually does not cause health problems beyond mild anemia. Thalassemia intermedia is a condition of moderate severity, in which people may have moderate to severe anemia, which sometimes requires treatment with blood transfusions. Thalassemia major is a severe form of beta-thalassemia that affects many aspects of health. Without treatment, signs and symptoms of this condition usually begin within the first 2 years of life. Affected children have severe anemia, which causes little energy (fatigue), irritability, and pale appearance. Affected children may also develop an abnormally enlarged spleen, heart problems, and slow growth rate. In thalassemia major, the body tries to compensate for the mild lack of oxygen supply caused by the anemia by increasing production of red blood cells, even though the cells are defective. This can result in expanded bone marrow spaces, which cause thinning and deformities of bones, especially in the face and skull.  Treatment for beta-thalassemia includes regular blood transfusions (to relieve severe anemia) and iron chelation therapy (to remove extra iron from the body). Bone marrow transplant is the only potential cure. In some cases, it can reverse bone deformities and allow children to resume normal growth rates.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What is (are) Bethlem myopathy ?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Bethlem myopathy (BM) is a disorder that causes muscle weakness and joint stiffness (contractures). BM is characterized by slowly progressive muscle weakness and contractures affecting the joints of the fingers, wrists, elbows, neck, and knees. BM is classified as a congenital myopathy.  The signs and symptoms of BM usually begin in the first 2 decades of life. Muscle weakness and skin stiffness (induration) are often the earliest features of the disease. Joint stiffness and muscle weakness continue to get worse, causing affected individuals to fall often and trip over their toes. As a result, many people with BM walk on the balls of their feet (toe walking). Other movement-related problems include a swaying gait (ataxia) and an abnormal side-to-side (laterally restricted) motion of the shoulders.  While BM begins in childhood in most cases, affected people may have few signs and symptoms later in adulthood and have a normal life expectancy. The muscle weakness associated with BM generally does not affect head, facial, or other muscles used for moving (skeletal muscles), although some affected individuals may experience weakness in these muscles. The other muscles of the body, such as those used for breathing (respiratory muscles), are rarely affected. Some older adults with BM develop stiff joints in their backs (spines), which can contribute to curvature of the spine (kyphosis).  Rarely, affected people develop recurrent stretches of strong muscle contractions in the forearm (\"forearm myositis\"), followed by painful muscle wasting and weakness (atrophy). In addition, some individuals have tight or thickened skin of the hands or abdomen. Occasionally, affected individuals have thin skin with veins that are very visible through the skin of the upper arms and legs, as well as herniation of muscles between the ribs. All of these signs and symptoms are considered typical of BM.  Other rare features have been reported in a few individuals with BM. Swelling (edema) of the limbs may be seen in infancy due to blockages (obstructions) in the blood vessels. Additional symptoms that have affected a small number of people with BM include curved toes (hitchhiker's toe sign), soft nails, loose joints, shortening of connective tissues throughout the body (generalized fibrosis), kidney failure, and small pupils that fail to constrict (respond) in bright light.  The age of onset, severity, and progression of BM can vary widely even among members of the same family.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What causes Bethlem myopathy ?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"What causes Bethlem myopathy? Bethlem myopathy is caused by mutations in either the COL6A1, COL6A2, or COL6A3 genes. These genes provide instructions for making three protein chains (alpha 1, alpha 2, and alpha 3) that combine to form a larger protein called type VI collagen.  Type VI collagen is an important part of the extracellular matrix, which provides support and stimuli crucial for controlling cell behavior and the development and repair of tissues. Type VI collagen forms a network of molecules that connect with other types of proteins in the extracellular matrix, including other collagens, helping to maintain the structural integrity of tissues. Type VI collagen also attaches (binds) muscle cells to the surrounding extracellular matrix. The binding of muscle cells to the extracellular matrix allows developed force within the cells to be transmitted across the muscle. The result is the contraction of individual muscle fibers and the entire muscle.  Type VI collagen is found throughout the body, but it plays an especially important role in skeletal muscles, which are used for movement. Mutations in COL6A1, COL6A2, or COL6A3 reduce the amount of type VI collagen that is produced or interfere with the ability of the individual alpha chains to assemble properly into type VI collagen trimers. Mutations also can disrupt the ability of the trimers to assemble correctly into the larger type VI collagen molecule or the collagen molecules to attach to each other to form the network that provides strength to the extracellular matrix. As a result, the skeletal muscles of affected people are more vulnerable to injury. Over time, repeated muscle damage results in muscle weakness and wasting, which are characteristic features of Bethlem myopathy. Researchers are not certain why some people with a mutation in one of the COL6 genes develop Bethlem myopathy and others develop Ullrich congenital muscular dystrophy. It is possible that the variation in signs and symptoms is influenced by the type or location of the COL6 gene mutation.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"What causes Bethlem myopathy? Bethlem myopathy is caused by genetic changes (mutations) in the COL6A1, COL6A2, or COL6A3 gene. All forms of this condition were previously thought to be inherited in an autosomal dominant manner; however, autosomal recessive inheritance also can occur. In autosomal dominant inheritance, the target gene has a mutation in one its two copies. In autosomal recessive inheritance, both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations. The parents of an individual with an autosomal recessive condition each carry one copy of the mutated gene, but they typically do not show signs and symptoms of the condition. The protein produced from the gene is called the type VI (6) collagen α 1-chain, α2-chain, or α3-chain. Collagen is a protein used to strengthen and add structure to many parts of the body, including muscles. The type VI collagen α 1-chain, α2-chain, or α3-chain is made up of several smaller molecules that twist around each other to form one large molecule. Several large molecules cluster together to form one type VI collage (or collagen alpha 1, 2 or 3) molecule. Clusters of type VI collagen molecules form fibers, called microfibrils, which attach to many other molecules to form connective tissue. The genetic changes that cause Bethlem myopathy can impair microfibril or connective tissue formation. As a result, muscles are weak, making movement difficult, and they are prone to injury. Tightening of the skin and the tissues that surround muscles (fascia) stiffens the joints.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Bietti crystalline corneoretinal dystrophy is an eye disorder that causes progressive vision loss. Common symptoms include shimmering, yellow crystals on the eye and fatty protein deposits. Additional features associated with this condition include corneal (the clear part of the eye) deposits, gradual atrophy of the retina, and a condition called choroidal sclerosis, which involves hardening of blood vessels at the back of the eye. Bietti crystalline corneoretinal dystrophy typically becomes apparent in the twenties or thirties. This disorder is caused by mutations in the CYP4V2 gene and is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. There is currently no cure; however, early detection is helpful given that much of the vision loss may be prevented through the management of eye complications.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Bietti crystalline corneoretinal dystrophy is an eye disease characterized by abnormalities in the retina, cornea, and conjunctiva. The condition typically becomes apparent in early adulthood and causes symptoms that progress slowly, eventually leading to vision impairment or blindness. In some cases, the symptoms progress quickly and vision loss can be significant by middle age. The hallmark feature of Bietti crystalline corneoretinal dystrophy is shiny, sparkling crystals in the retina; up to 90 percent of affected individuals also have crystals in the cornea, conjunctiva, or both. Additional eye abnormalities develop with age, including atrophy (degeneration) of the choroid and retina, an irregularly shaped pupil, and small white deposits on the sclerae.  Early symptoms of Bietti crystalline corneoretinal dystrophy can include night blindness (nyctalopia) and increased sensitivity to glare. Later loss of the retina's light-sensing cells (photoreceptors) impairs sharpness of vision (visual acuity) and causes blind spots in the center of the visual field (central scotomas). Over time, an expanding ring of pigment develops around the macula, a region at the back of the eye important for sharp central vision. As the macula becomes increasingly damaged, peripheral (side) vision is affected, causing tunnel vision. Many people with Bietti crystalline corneoretinal dystrophy eventually become legally blind, but their vision loss is not typically severe enough to cause complete blindness.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Bietti crystalline corneoretinal dystrophy (BCD) is an eye disorder characterized by abnormalities that involve progressive vision loss. Typically, people with BCD develop glistening, crystal-like deposits in specific areas of the eyes called the cornea (the clear tissue at the front of the eye) and retina (the light-sensitive tissue at the back of the eye). These deposits can occur as the eyes grow and change before birth, or in early childhood.  BCD also causes a condition called chorioretinal atrophy. In this disorder, certain tissues in the retina and a nearby membrane (the choroid) become thin and wasted away (atrophied), impairing vision. Chorioretinal atrophy usually develops after the crystal-like deposits appear. As the chorioretinal atrophy worsens, vision loss occurs.  Vision problems in BCD generally begin between the late teenage years and mid-thirties. About half of affected individuals eventually retain only very limited sight, such as awareness of light and dark. Others lose all light perception, resulting in complete blindness. Some people with BCD, however, live into late adulthood with mild vision loss and some remaining sight.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Bietti crystalline corneoretinal dystrophy is a disorder that causes progressive damage to the retina, resulting in worsening vision that can lead to blindness. Most cases of Bietti crystalline corneoretinal dystrophy are caused by mutations in the CYP4V2 gene and the condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. prompt: What is (are) Bilateral frontal polymicrogyria ?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Bilateral frontal polymicrogyria is an abnormality (malformation) of the brain that affects the development of the frontal lobes, which are the parts of the brain behind the forehead. Polymicrogyria means \"many small folds.\" Normally, the surface of the brain has folds (gyri) and grooves (sulci) that give it a wrinkled appearance. In people with polymicrogyria, the folds in the cerebral cortex have an unusually small and irregular appearance. Bilateral frontal polymicrogyria is a specific pattern of polymicrogyria that is usually symmetrical (the same on both sides) and limited to the frontal lobes.  The signs and symptoms of bilateral polymicrogyria generally begin in childhood. Affected children may have mild to moderate intellectual disability. They may experience developmental delay, in which milestones such as sitting, walking, and talking are delayed. Developmental delay can also affect areas related to social and emotional interaction (social delay, autistic tendencies) and communication (speech delay).  Many children with bilateral polymicrogyria have seizures (epilepsy). The epilepsy can be severe and resistant to treatment; in these cases, the condition is called bilateral frontal polymicrogyria and perisylvian polymicrogyria with epilepsy. Some children with this form of the disorder also have acquired microcephaly; this term means their head size was typical at birth but their brain growth slowed in early childhood and the head size did not increase as would be expected.  Bilateral polymicrogyria can occur due to damage to the brain during development. It can also be associated with certain genetic disorders, such as Aicardi-Goutieres syndrome, bilateral frontonasal malformation with bilateral frontal polymicrogyria, and X-linked tubulin alpha-1 chain (TUBA1A)-related disorder. A region on the short (p) arm of the X chromosome called Xp11 has been linked to bilateral frontal polymicrogyria in some families.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

The \"wrinkles\" in the folds (gyri) are unusually small and more numerous. In bilateral frontal polymicrogyria, the abnormal folds are in the front (frontal) part of the brain which controls reasoning, problem-solving, speech and language, emotions, and learning.  Affected individuals may have additional folds in other parts of the brain.  Polymicrogyria results in a wide range of neurologic problems and causes signifcant disability.  In most affected individuals, movement (motor) problems are present, and many have intellectual disability or developmental delay and seizures.  Polygenic inheritance likely accounts for some cases though others are not inherited.  Polymicrogyria can occur haphazardly as an isolated event during brain development; in these cases no specific cause is known. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Bilateral frontal polymicrogyria (BFPMG) is a disorder of brain development associated with intellectual disability and difficulty moving certain muscles of the face, mouth, and throat (oromotor dysfunction). At birth, infants with BFPMG are unusually stiff (hypertonic) and have difficulty controlling the movement of their faces and mouths, including grimacing, sucking, swallowing, and making sounds. Oromotor dysfunction contributes to feeding problems, speech delays, and choking episodes. Some affected individuals also have a high-arched or cleft palate.  BFPMG leads to abnormal patterns of muscle development and control (muscle tone abnormalities known as dystonia or athetosis) and uncontrollable movements (congenital athetotic tetraparesis) that primarily affect the four limbs (tetraparesis). As a result, some children with BFPMG are unable to control their hands or walk, while others are able to use their hands and walk but with difficulty. Individuals with BFPMG may also have seizures that begin in infancy.  The signs and symptoms of BFPMG become less severe with age. Muscle stiffness and uncontrolled movements lessen, or these problems may disappear entirely. Oromotor dysfunction diminishes and feeding problems resolve. However, most people with BFPMG continue to have difficulty controlling certain facial and mouth movements, which leads to speech difficulties. While seizures typically continue into adulthood, the affected individuals' seizures generally become less severe.  BFPMG is caused by mutations in the WDR62 gene. This disorder is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations. The parents of an individual with an autosomal recessive condition each carry one copy of the mutated gene, but they typically do not show signs and symptoms of the condition.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

With polymicrogyria, the folds are unusually small, and there can be more folds than normal. The abnormal folds can occur in a specific area of the brain or can be distributed more globally throughout the brain. In bilateral frontal polymicrogyria, patterns of polymicrogyria tend to be symmetrical and involve parts of the brain known as the frontal lobes, which are near the front of the brain behind the forehead. The extent of the polymicrogyria can vary. prompt: What is (are) Bilateral frontoparietal polymicrogyria ?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Bilateral frontoparietal polymicrogyria (BFPP) is an uncommon brain disorder that is present at birth (congenital). Affected individuals typically have weak muscle tone (hypotonia) and markedly delayed growth of motor skills in infancy. Subsequently, most have mild to severe intellectual disability and poorly developed speech. Some affected individuals also have epilepsy. Behavioral issues such as irritability and inability to focus are also common. Language and social skills tend to be less impaired than motor skills, meaning that BFPP does not result in frank autism.   The specific constellation of brain abnormalities seen in BFPP leads to the neurological impairments characteristic of the condition. A key brain abnormality is a defect in how the folds of the brain, known as gyrus (gyri), develop - an abnormality known as polymicrogyria. The polymicrogyria is most prominent in the front (frontal lobe) and side (parietal lobe) regions of the cerebrum, which is the part of the brain responsible for conscious thought, speech, sensory processing, and voluntary movement.  A variety of additional cerebral malformations can result, such as hydrocephalus (an abnormal buildup of fluid in the brain that can increase pressure, expand the skull, and damage brain tissue), areas of low brain tissue volume (hypoplasia) and a crystalline deposit in the middle of the brain (iron deposition in the basal ganglia). Polymicrogyria in BFPP is also associated with misplacement or abnormal development of nerve cells in the white matter, which is the tissue through which nerve impulses are transmitted. Myelin, a fatty material that insulates nerve cells and helps nerve signals travel efficiently, is also abnormally deposited in BFPP. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can detect these characteristic brain abnormalities in people affected with BFPP.   BFPP is caused by a change (mutation) in the gene GPR56. It is typically inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.   NIH: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

The severity of signs and symptoms of bilateral frontoparietal polymicrogyria varies among affected individuals. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Bilateral frontoparietal polymicrogyria is a brain disorder that results from abnormal development of the brain before birth. The term \"polymicrogyria\" refers to an excessive number of small folds (gyri) in the outermost layer of the brain. In this disorder, these brain abnormalities typically involve the frontal lobes (brain regions located just behind the forehead) and parietal lobes (brain regions near the middle of the brain towards the top and back of the head). Genetic mutations can cause bilateral frontoparietal polymicrogyria to be an inherited condition.  People with bilateral frontoparietal polymicrogyria typically have muscle weakness in the arms and legs and decreased muscle tone (hypotonia), though the severity of these features can vary widely. Decreased muscle tone in combination with the weakness of the limbs usually results in delayed motor development in infancy (e.g., slowing in the age at which a child with this disorder will sit independently or walk). Additional features can include cognitive impairment or intellectual disability ranging from mild to severe; seizures, especially absent seizures; difficulty speaking due to impaired movements in the muscles used in speech (dysarthria); small head size (microcephaly); and joint abnormalities such as unusual joint angles (contractures) and/or swelling of joints due to fluid buildup (edema). Many people also have vision problems, such as partial or complete blindness, involuntary rapid eye movements (nystagmus), and small or unusually shaped eyes (coloboma).  Bilateral frontoparietal polymicrogyria can result from genetic mutations in several genes. A half to two-thirds of affected people have no known history of the condition in their families and are thought to have a new (de novo) genetic mutation that occurred spontaneously around the time of conception. In these cases, the condition typically results from mutations in the PIK3R2 or PIK3CA genes. When it is inherited, it is usually passed through families in an autosomal dominant pattern and results from mutations in the genes GPR56 or TUBB2B. The Sylvian fissure is the deep fold that separates the temporal lobe (which controls understanding of language and speech and certain types of memory) from part of the parietal lobe and the frontal lobe (which controls movement, thinking, and problem-solving). The polymicrogyria results in abnormal function of these regions.  The symptoms of BPP vary in severity depending on the extent of the brain malformation. Some individuals have very mild symptoms, while others have severe developmental problems.  Common signs and symptoms of BPP may include speech difficulties; swallowing problems; varying degrees of cognitive impairment; muscle weakness, paralysis on one side of the body, or complete lack of muscle tone; uncontrolled contractions of the muscles (seizures); and in rare cases, joints that are stiff and have limited range of motion. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Bilateral perisylvian polymicrogyria (BPP) is a neurological condition characterized by abnormal development of brain cells and brain activity. The condition has three main features: an abnormal arrangement of brain folds and grooves (polymicrogyria), problems controlling facial movements (dysarthria), and disturbed movement of the tongue, throat, and mouth region (pseudobulbar paresis).  The condition nearly always affects folds and grooves on the outer surface of a particular part of the brain, which is known as the perisylvian region. This region of the brain carries information for movement and sensations in the face and mouth, so impairments can lead to dysarthria and pseudobulbar paresis. In some cases, the condition extends more broadly in the brain, with polymicrogyria affecting other regions and causing intellectual disability, epilepsy, or other issues.  Children with BPP typically have mild-to-moderate intellectual disability and delayed development of motor skills. Those with BPP often experience seizures, which appear to be correlated with the amount of polymicrogyria in the brain. Mobility problems range from mild to severe, but people with more extensive polymicrogyria in the brain usually have more severe problems and can require a wheelchair. About one-fourth of people with BPP are also affected by a downward arch of the mouth and limited range of motion for the upper arms. This presentation is known as arthrogryposis multiplex congenita.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

In bilateral perisylvian polymicrogyria, normal brain folds are replaced by many small, malformed folds in an area around the Sylvian fissure, a prominent groove on the surface of the brain. The abnormal folds damage the nerve cells that control movement, speech, cognition and sensory processing, causing movement problems (e.g., abnormal tremors), speech delay and/or speech difficulty, learning problems, seizures and feeding difficulties. The deep areas of the brain that are affected by this disorder are called the basal ganglia and thalami; these areas help regulate movement. In bilateral perisylvian polymicrogyria, these areas may shrink, have an abnormal shape, or be fused together. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Binswanger's disease is a type of dementia caused by damage to the white matter of the brain. The white matter consists of nerves covered by myelin, the fatty material that protects and insulates nerve fibers. It connects various to areas of the brain and helps nerve fibers transmit signals in an efficient manner. Binswanger's disease, also called subcortical vascular dementia or subcortical leukoencephalopathy, is believed to result from damage to small blood vessels in this part of the brain.       Damage to the white matter can lead to loss of memory, difficulties thinking or understanding, loss of bladder control and difficulty with walking, problems speaking, and personality changes. The loss of nerve cells involved in regulating muscle control in the legs can cause a loss of balance and difficulty walking. Similarly, decline in other cognitive abilities such as judgment and attention can interfere with other movements such as orienting one's body in space. Damage to nerves can also affect the ability to speak clearly, resulting in slower speech with a stutter. People with Binswanger's disease may become apathetic or show obsessive-compulsive behavior. Behavioral and psychiatric symptoms such as depression, irritability, agitation, delusions, and hallucinations may also be present.      Premature loss of taste and smell, incontinence, problems walking, and difficulty speaking are generally not associated with Alzheimer's disease and may help distinguish Binswanger's disease from Alzheimer's disease. However, people with longstanding high blood pressure may have features of Binswanger's disease. Features of other types of dementia may also be present. prompt: What is (are) Biotinidase deficiency ?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Biotinidase deficiency is a disorder in which the body is unable to reuse and recycle the vitamin biotin. Biotin plays an important role in the metabolism of proteins, fats, and carbohydrates. A shortage of the vitamin can impair the functioning of many organs, including the nervous system.  In most cases, the signs and symptoms of biotinidase deficiency begin between the 2nd and 6th month of life, although affected children may develop problems any time during infancy. Some infants with biotinidase deficiency are born with no symptoms; however, without treatment, neurological problems develop eventually. In this disorder, neurological signs and symptoms are typically seen; seizures are documented in as many as 70% of cases. Developmental delay and longer-term neurological damage such as ataxia and cognitive disabilities are often present as well. Other signs and symptoms that may be associated with biotinidase deficiency include skin rash and alopecia (loss of hair from the scalp).  Although biotinidase deficiency is typically categorized as having two different types (profound and partial), signs and symptoms can vary widely, even within the individual types. Biotinidase is the enzyme that frees biotin from proteins in the diet so it can be used again. An individual with profound biotinidase deficiency is unable to reuse biotin, while an individual with partial biotinidase deficiency has some ability to reuse biotin.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Biotinidase deficiency is a disorder in which the body is unable to reuse and recycle the vitamin biotin. In people with this condition, the body cannot break certain proteins down into their building blocks (a process called proteolytic catabolism) to release biotin. As a result, biotin is not available for use in the metabolism of carbohydrates, fats, and proteins.  Biotinidase deficiency usually becomes apparent in infants between the ages of 3 and 6 months. Affected babies generally develop neurological problems, including seizures, low muscle tone (hypotonia), movement disorders, vision problems, and hearing loss. Developmental delay and mental retardation also occur. Affected children can develop skin problems, including patches of scaly skin (exfoliative dermatitis) and a red rash (erythematous perianal rash), as well as loss of hair and eyelashes (alopecia).  About half of people with biotinidase deficiency do not have signs and symptoms of the disorder during infancy, but most will experience some neurological symptoms as they grow older. Sporadic seizures or a movement disorder such as tremor or tics can occur. Affected individuals can have abnormal gait and ataxia. Vision or hearing loss may be present. Some people self-describe as having a foggy or tired feeling, especially after eating protein-containing foods. Later, individuals can develop gymnastics-like movements (jumps, flips, and spinning) and, rarely, more serious complications such as coma, deafness and blindness, or even death.  The symptoms of biotinidase deficiency are similar in onset and appearance to the symptoms of holocarboxylase synthetase deficiency. However, the two disorders can be distinguished by biochemical studies.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Biotinidase deficiency is a metabolic disorder that causes a shortage (deficiency) of biotin, also called vitamin B7. Biotin is important for the function of proteins called enzymes (or biocatalysts) within your body. Some enzymes that require biotin are needed to break down proteins, fats, and carbohydrates from the diet. Other enzymes that require biotin are needed for gluconeogenesis, a process that forms glucose (sugar). Biotinidase is an enzyme that helps recycle biotin. Without biotinidase people may become biotin deficient.  Biotin deficiency can cause problems with handling fats and carbohydrates from the diet and gluconeogenesis. When this occurs it can lead to acid build-up in the blood (acidosis) and problems with the nervous system including brain swelling (encephalopathy), muscle weakness, low muscle tone, problems moving, seizures, rash around the mouth and anus, hair loss and developmental delay. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Biotinidase deficiency is an inherited metabolic disorder in which the body is unable to reuse and recycle the vitamin biotin. In its free form, biotin is absorbed from foods and supplements. When biotin is bound to proteins, it is released and recycled by an enzyme called biotinidase. In individuals with biotinidase deficiency, the enzyme is absent or reduced, which interferes with the body's ability to reuse and recycle biotin from food. Individuals with the disorder have a biotin deficiency that affects the function of four other enzymes: (1) acetyl-CoA carboxylase and propionyl-CoA carboxylase, which help break down fats and help regulate glucose (blood sugar) production from noncarbohydrate sources,(2) beta-methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase, which helps break down the amino acid leucine, and (3) pyruvate carboxylase, which is used in gluconeogenesis, the metabolic pathway that produces glucose.  In untreated infants with profound biotinidase deficiency, the first signs of the disorder typically appear between two and four months of age and include seizures and loss of appetite. Affected infants may also be unable to coordinate movements, have weak muscle tone (hypotonia), develop a red scaly rash around body openings (perioral and perianal dermatitis), show delays in reaching developmental milestones, as well as delays in speech and motor skills, and experience vision and hearing loss. Many infants also experience hyperventilation, which may be triggered by overexcitement, pain, or heat.  Delayed treatment of affected infants can result in conditions such as ataxia, coma, breathing problems, tremors, nystagmus (a condition that causes involuntary eye movement), poor growth, hair loss, and optic atrophy, which can lead to blindness.  In some individuals with partial biotinidase deficiency, signs and symptoms, such as seizures and developmental delay, appear in childhood or adolescence. Mild learning delays and mild social difficulties have also been observed in some affected children.  Without treatment, an affected individual with profound biotinidase deficiency may live only into early childhood. Biotin supplements can prevent the symptoms of the disorder.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Birdshot chorioretinopathy, also known as birdshot retinochoroiditis, is a chronic, bilateral, inflammatory eye disease of the retina and choroid. Birdshot chorioretinopathy is classified as a form of posterior uveitis or panuveitis and represents only 0.5-1.5% of all cases of uveitis. The disease mainly affects whites of Northern European descent, with few, if any, cases in African Americans reported. Birdshot chorioretinopathy tends to affect people in middle age but has been diagnosed in childhood in rare cases. Females and males appear to be affected equally.    Early symptoms of birdshot chorioretinopathy may include: mild blurring, flashing lights, floaters, variable dull eye pain, and/or redness. Some cases may begin with conjunctivitis. The most commonly reported symptoms include decreased night vision and floaters. Fluorescein angiography may reveal leakage and delayed filling of the retinal blood vessels. A \"sunset glow\" appearance, or depigmentation of the retina, may be noted. Over time, vision may become moderately to severely impaired. In rare cases a loss of peripheral vision or color vision may be noted. If untreated, patients typically experience severe loss of central acuity (i.e., clarity/sharpness of vision) by 5-10 years.    Clinical examination reveals scattered patches of depigmentation or hypopigmented \"birdshot\" lesions in the midperiphery or periphery of the retina. The birdshot lesions are variably sized and shaped and tend not to involve the macula or optic disc. Over time, the patches become more prominent and well delineated. Macular edema and optic nerve swelling may be observed. Inflammation may affect the iris, ciliary body, vitreous humor, and peripheral retina.    The cause of birdshot chorioretinopathy remains unknown. There appears to be an association with a certain genetic marker (i.e., human leukocyte antigen (HLA)-A29). Birdshot chorioretinopathy is not contagious, is not known to be genetic, and all forms of treatment are off-label. Long term immunosuppressive therapy is usually necessary and involves drugs with notable risks of serious side effects. With treatment, about 85 percent of patients with birdshot chorioretinopathy maintain near normal vision, and 40 percent of patients recover vision that is better than it was before treatment.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Birdshot chorioretinopathy (chorioretinitis) is a rare form of posterior uveitis, a group of inflammatory diseases involving the back part of the eye. This inflammation is also called a flare-up or a relapse. Inflammation is part of the body's immune response. However, if it's not regulated, inflammation can lead to tissue damage, which can interfere with vision in birdshot chorioretinopathy. People with birdshot chorioretinopathy experience periods of reduced inflammation or no inflammation at all; this is called remission. Birdshot chorioretinopathy tends to be a chronic, long-lasting condition.  Aside from the pale spots pattern that appears in the choroid, signs and symptoms of birdshot chorioretinopathy may include blurred vision, decreased night vision, floaters, flashes of light, and loss of color contrast sensitivity. Some affected individuals have no symptoms. Without treatment, uveitis may be associated with complications including cataracts, glaucoma, and macular edema. Treatment for birdshot chorioretinopathy (BSCR) has improved greatly in recent years as newer and more effective treatment options have been explored. In the past with the \"classical\" approach to treatment, most patients still developed some degree of visual impairment from searching (scotomas), light sensitivity, decreased night vision and/or blurring. Usually each affected family member goes through several different types of treatments with specialists in the field and many years of follow up. This seemingly lengthy process is because the disease may occur in flares with periods of remission in between. The goal of treatment is adequate control of inflammation to prevent visual loss. Usually a combination of treatments (immunosuppressive drugs, corticosteroids, immune-modulatory treatments, chemotherapy, or newer biologics like Adalimumab) is required to get inflammation under control and then kept suppressed to prevent further attacks. Treatment generally lasts years and in most cases, is not curative. With effective treatment, most patients with BSCR have stable vision. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome is an inherited disorder characterized by skin abnormalities, lung cysts, pneumothorax, and an increased risk of kidney cancer. Skin abnormalities appear in almost all people with this disorder. They consist of three related growths called fibrofolliculomas, trichodiscomas, and acrochordons (also called skin tags).  Most of these growths are benign (not cancerous) and do not cause serious health problems. They usually appear as groups of small, white or flesh-colored bumps on the face, neck, and upper torso in early adulthood. These growths are rarely seen in infant or young children with Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome.  Lung cysts develop in more than 80 percent of people with the disorder. They are surrounded by an abnormal accumulation of fluid called edema. The cysts do not usually cause symptoms and are most often detected by imaging performed for another reason. In some affected people, the cysts interfere with normal lung function. They can also rupture and cause a collapsed lung (pneumothorax). Pneumothorax occurs in an estimated 24 to 38 percent of people with Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome.  About one-third of people with Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome develop tumors (also called neoplasms) in the kidneys, also called renal tumors or renal cell carcinomas (RCCs). These tumors can be benign or malignant (cancerous). People with Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome often develop tumors in both kidneys and can have multiple tumors in each kidney. When these tumors are malignant, they are usually slow growing and likely to be large with a mixture of different kinds of cancer cells. Kidney tumors are rare in children with this disorder. This summary does not include information about the treatment of skin tumors, kidney tumors, or lung cysts associated with Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"What are the signs and symptoms of Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome? Birt-Hogg-Dube (BHD) syndrome causes benign growths of the skin, lung cysts, spontaneous pneumothorax (collapsed lung), and renal tumors. Genetic home reference lists these as the signs and symptoms of BHD: Multiple bumps (fibrofolliculomas) or skin growths (trichodiscomas and acrochordons) on the face, neck, and upper torso Areas of excess hair growth (hypertrichosis) on the head Benign growths of the intestinal wall (diverticula) Spontaneous pneumothorax (lung collapse) due to multiple lung cysts. This usually occurs after an accident or injury. Large kidney (renal) tumors. The tumors may be benign or malignant. Other sources list the signs and symptoms of BHD as: skin tumors that usually appear after age 20; occur as multiple growths; and can increase in number and size over time; kidney tumors; and lung cysts that may lead to spontaneous pneumothorax. Management of Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome includes close monitoring for serious renal tumors. Small renal tumors could be treated with nephron-sparing surgery, radiofrequency ablation, or cryoablation. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"How might Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome be treated? Treatment for Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome is symptomatic. Affected individuals should work with a multidisciplinary team of healthcare professionals, including a dermatologist, a pulmonologist, and/or a geneticist, to help them manage signs and symptoms as they occur.  In particular, it is important for affected individuals to have regular monitoring of their lungs and kidneys. Pulmonary function tests and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the lungs should be performed regularly to monitor the number and size of lung cysts. MRI, ultrasound, and/or computerized tomography (CT) of the kidneys should be performed regularly to check for signs of tumors. Once tumors are detected, surgery remains the best option for affected individuals.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}
