These eye-lid malformations can occur alone or together in a pattern known as blepharophimosis, ptosis, and epicanthus inversus syndrome. BPES is highly heterogeneous; it can appear as an isolated eye-lid abnormality (type 2), or it can be associated with premature ovarian failure and fertility problems in affected females (type 1). BPES is caused by changes in the FOXL2 gene and is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner. Treatment depends on the specific signs and symptoms present in each person. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Blepharophimosis, ptosis, and epicanthus inversus syndrome (BPES) is a rare condition characterized by abnormalities of the eyelids. There are two different types of this condition, which are distinguished by the presence or absence of an additional sign. With type 2 BPES, females do not experience early menopause. In nearly all cases, the eyelid abnormalities characteristic of BPES are present before birth. Two types of blepharophimosis, ptosis, and epicanthus inversus syndrome have been identified: type 1 and type 2. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"This condition can be inherited in an autosomal dominant or autosomal recessive pattern. Autosomal dominant inheritance means only one copy of an altered gene is necessary to cause the disorder. In these cases, an affected person has one copy of the altered gene and one normal gene in each cell. Some people who have autosomal dominant inherited blepharophimosis, ptosis, and epicanthus inversus syndrome do not have an affected parent; instead, they have a new mutation in the gene (also called a de novo mutation). This new mutation occurred in the egg or sperm from which they were conceived or shortly after conception. These people have one altered copy of the gene in each cell.  Autosomal recessive inheritance means two copies of an altered gene are necessary to cause the disorder. Those who have an autosomal recessively inherited form of this syndrome have two mutated copies in each cell. People with one mutated copy are called carriers. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"How might blepharophimosis, ptosis, and epicanthus inversus syndrome be treated? Individuals with blepharophimosis, ptosis, and epicanthus inversus syndrome (BPES) may have varying degrees of eyelid problems including a narrowing of the upper eyelids (blepharophimosis), drooping eyelids (ptosis), a fold of skin in the corner of the eyelids covering the inner angle of the eye (epicanthus), and eyelid retraction. These eyelid problems may restrict the opening of the eye and interfere with vision. The eyelid problems can be corrected with a series of surgeries designed to improve the eyelids, eye opening, and vision. In affected females, BPES may occur with POI and the POI should be addressed medically (e.g. possible hormone replacement therapy) and/or surgically (e.g. hysterectomy, salpingectomy, oophorectomy).","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Blepharophimosis, ptosis, and epicanthus inversus syndrome (BPES) affects the eyelids. The four major features of BPES are blepharophimosis, ptosis, epicanthus inversus, and telecanthus. People with BPES type 1 also have reduced ovarian function (called ovarian follicular dysfunction), which can lead to abnormalities in the ovaries and female infertility. In BPES type 2, ovarian function is not affected.  Blepharophimosis means the eyelid openings are abnormally narrow. Ptosis is a drooping of the upper eyelids that can cover the eyes and interfere with vision. Epicanthus inversus is a skin fold that comes from the lower eyelid and covers the inner corner of the eye. Telecanthus is an increased distance between the inner corners of the eye.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Blepharophimosis, ptosis, and epicanthus inversus syndrome (BPES) is a condition that affects the eyelids.  People with BPES have eyelids that may be underdeveloped or misshaped. Together, the eyelid features can narrow the opening between the eyes (blepharophimosis), cause the upper eyelids to droop (ptosis), and cause skin folds under the eyes to fold in the opposite direction than normal (epicanthus inversus). These eyelid features are apparent at birth and typically do not worsen with age. Other eyelid problems can occur as a result, including crossed eyes (strabismus), eyes that do not point in the same direction (ocular misalignment), and eyes that don't open fully. Vision is usually normal in affected people, but may be impaired if eyelid problems are left untreated.  People with BPES are classified as having one of two types of the condition. In type 1 BPES, affected people have eyelid problems and, in females, reduced ovarian function (also known as premature ovarian failure). In type 2, affected individuals have the characteristic eyelid features but do not have reduced ovarian function.  BPES is caused by changes in the FOXL2 gene and is inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Blepharophimosis, ptosis, and epicanthus inversus syndrome (BPES) is a condition mainly involving eyelid abnormalities. Two different types of BPES have been described:  Type 1 includes eyelid malformations and an associated reduced level of female fertility, or premature ovarian failure. Type 2 is limited to eyelid abnormalities.  The eyelid abnormalities that occur in BPES include blepharophimosis (underdeveloped eyelids), ptosis (low-set eyelids), epicanthus inversus (a fold of skin that runs from the bottom of the nose to the upper eyelid), and telecanthus (wide spacing between the upper eyelids). The eyelid abnormalities are apparent early in life, and most affected people require eye surgery to correct these problems and improve vision. These distinctive facial abnormalities give people with BPES a characteristic appearance; however, the disorder typically does not affect eye function.  Less commonly, BPES has been associated with other abnormalities, including signs and symptoms of premature aging; skeletal, nasal, palatal, hand and foot, genitourinary, and heart defects; and variable intellectual disability. However, these features are not consistently found in BPES and are thought to be caused by genetic changes that affect multiple neighboring genes.  FOXL2 gene mutations cause BPES. BPES results from the loss of one functional copy of the FOXL2 gene in each cell.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Blepharophimosis, ptosis, and epicanthus inversus syndrome (BPES) is a condition that affects the eyelids. People with BPES have four main eyelid abnormalities: blepharophimosis, ptosis, epicanthus inversus, and telecanthus. A fifth eyelid abnormality, entropion, is sometimes seen with BPES. Researchers have described two types of BPES: type 1 and type 2. Type 1 causes eyelid abnormalities and a group of symptoms known as ovarian follicle dysfunction that affects female sex organs. Ovarian follicle dysfunction often causes a condition called premature ovarian failure (POF), which can lead to infertility. In contrast, type 2 affects only the eyelids and does not affect fertility. Rarely, both reproductive problems and infertility are seen in individuals with type 2.  These eye and reproductive features occur because of changes (mutations) in different areas of the forkhead box L2 (FOXL2) gene. This gene provides instructions for making a type of protein called a transcription factor. Transcription factors bind to DNA and turn genes on or off. The FOXL2 transcription factor plays a role in the development of the eyelids before birth and in the development of sex organs, especially the ovaries.  BPES is usually inherited as an autosomal dominant trait. This means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder. In some cases, an individual with BPES does not have any affected relatives.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Blepharophimosis, ptosis, and epicanthus inversus syndrome (BPES) is a condition that affects the eyelids and sometimes affects ovarian development in women. The condition causes severe narrowing of the eye opening (blepharophimosis), drooping of the upper eyelids (ptosis), an upward fold of skin from the lower eyelid (epicanthus inversus), and a fold of skin at the inner corner of the eye that can cause the eyes to appear wide-set (telecanthus). These eyelid problems are evident at birth. Two forms of BPES are distinguished by whether the condition also affects female fertility. Type 1 (also called the \"classic\" form of BPES) can lead to infertility in affected women due to premature ovarian failure (POF); it affects only women. Type 2 does not affect fertility and can affect either sex. Both types of BPES are caused by mutations in the FOXL2 gene.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What is (are) Blepharospasm ?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Blepharospasm is a type of focal dystonia that causes abnormal blinking patterns, spasms of the eyelids, or both. People with this disorder may find that their eyes cross, turn upward or downward, or remain shut for increasing amounts of time. Some people cannot open their eyes at all for brief or extended periods, causing them to be virtually blind.  In the most severe cases, blepharospasm interferes with a person's ability to perform activities of daily living such as reading, cooking, eating, and driving.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Blepharospasm is the involuntary blinking or spasm of the eyelids. Isolated blepharospasm is a type of focal dystonia, a disorder which affects specific areas of the body. The exact cause of blepharospasm is unknown. Researchers believe that it may develop as a result of a combination of genetic and environmental factors. In some cases, blepharospasm may occur in conjunction with other neurological conditions.  The main feature of blepharospasm is involuntary blinking or spasming of the eyelids. Mild symptoms include the need to rub the eyes, close the eyes, blink, or yawn. Eye or forehead pain, eye irritation, sensitivity to light (photophobia), and dry eyes are sometimes reported. Other features can include involuntary grimacing or tics. Symptoms may continue for weeks or months before the onset of the actual spasms.  Symptoms tend to progress over time. Isolated blepharospasm may be relieved, at least temporarily, by touching under the nose, below the lower eyelid, or on the back of the head. This is called a sensory trick or 'geste antagoniste'.  There is not a cure for blepharospasm but treatments are available to help reduce the spasms. These treatments include eye lubricants, tinted glasses to reduce glare, stress management, and regular sleep. In some cases, people may consider eyelid surgery in order to reduce the symptoms. Botox injections are the first line of medical therapy. In 1989, the FDA approved Botox for the treatment of blepharospasm.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Blepharospasm is a neurological condition in which there is involuntary tight closure of the eyelids.  During involuntary eyelid closure, affected individuals may squeeze their eyes shut for a few seconds to a few minutes, and sometimes longer. Initially these spasms may occur in response to bright lights, wind, or tiredness, but over time these stimulation are no longer needed to trigger the eyelid spasms. Often individuals are able to voluntarily open their eyelids during the spasms, although it may require concentrated effort. The spasms may be misdiagnosed as seizures.  In some cases, eyelid spasms interfere with performing activities that require concentration and vision, such as reading, and even driving. Blepharospasm is different from \"dry eyes\". Most individuals with blepharospasm do not have changes in the anatomy of the eyelids or eye. In addition to the spasms, affected individuals may have eye symptoms including excessive tearing or eye irritation.   Over time, the spasms may worsen and occur more frequently or last longer. Studies suggest that blepharospasm may spread to other areas of the face in 1/3 to 1/2 of affected people. Spasms involving other parts of the face or neck may cause problems with speech and chewing. However, in most cases, blepharospasm remains limited to the eyelids. Symptoms usually reach their worst level and then begin to partially improve some time during the first 3 to 5 years.   In addition to blepharospasm, affected individuals may have other nearby areas of muscle spasms, often called \"cranial dystonia\". The frequency of cranial dystonia varies based n the population; one study of the Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale frequency measure suggests a frequency of approximately 74% while a study of a Taiwanese population suggests a frequency of approximately 12%. \"Blepharospasm-cranial dystonia\" includes symptoms of blepharospasm and at least one other area of cranial dystonia, such as lower facial, jaw, or neck spasms; oromandibular dystonia; or Meige syndrome.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

It is a relatively rare condition that affects the growth of the shin bone below the knee, causing it to bow outward. This results in a lower leg that angles inward. There are two main types of Blount disease:  Infantile Blount disease appears between the ages of 1 and 3 years.    Adolescent Blount disease appears as bowing of the legs later in childhood.  The exact cause of Blount disease is unknown. It can affect both legs, but in some cases only one leg is affected. It most commonly occurs in overweight children of African or Scandinavian descent. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Blount disease is a growth disorder of the shin bone (tibia) that causes the lower leg to angle inward, resembling a bowleg. This disorder is characterized by an abnormal growth at the top of the tibia, just below the knee. In Blount disease, the growth plate at the top of the tibia slows down or stops growing, resulting in a limb deformity. In severe cases of Blount disease, as the shin bone becomes more bowed, additional symptoms may occur including knee pain and/or tenderness swollen knee joint increased pressure on the foot causing the child to walk on the outside of the foot or the sole becomes slanted (everted) ankles that are slanted inward (inverted) obese, active children may complain of knee pain or show signs of arthritis less active children may have bowed legs with limited joint pain or signs of arthritis When Blount disease is delayed in treatment, signs may worsen and additional abnormalities may appear. Obesity, bowed legs or joint arthritis may contribute to additional medical problems including emotional issues, social isolation, low self-esteem, anorexia, and short stature.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Blount disease is an abnormality of the growth (epiphyseal) cartilage of the shinbone (tibia). This region of the cartilage is at the top of the shinbone adjacent to the knee joint. The problem leads to a growth disturbance of the inner, posterior portion of the tibia while the outer part grows normally. The result is a bowing of the entire lower leg due to the growth abnormality at the tibial epiphyseal and growth plate (physis). Although the underlying causes of Blount disease are unknown, both genetic and acquired factors may be involved. Conditions associated with this growth disturbance include obesity, early walking and carrying excess weight, and being African-American. There are two types of Blount disease, which are distinguished by the age of onset of the condition: infantile and adolescent. The bowing of the legs in infantile Blount disease is different than the bowing of the legs that normally develops in toddlers. Adolescent Blount disease, which begins between the ages of 10 and 16 years, may occur in one leg or both legs. Treatment may include a variety of surgical options.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Blount disease is a growth disorder of the shin bone (tibia) that causes the lower leg to angle inward, resembling a bowleg. The disorder occurs in two forms, infantile and adolescent, and is classified by the age when signs and symptoms appear. Signs and symptoms of the infantile form of the condition typically begin between birth and 3 years of age. It usually occurs in children who start walking at an early age or children who are overweight. It is twice as common in girls as in boys, and is more common in African Americans. This form of Blount disease typically affects both legs.  Signs and symptoms of the adolescent form of Blount disease usually become apparent after 10 years of age. This form of the condition usually occurs in children who are overweight and  often affects only one leg. Most affected adolescents are African American or Hispanic.  The bowing of the legs seen in Blount disease usually is apparent before the age of 2. However, other disorders can cause the legs to bow. Because some bowing of the legs is typical until 3 years of age, Blount disease can be difficult to diagnose, and it sometimes is mistaken for rickets. The infantile form of Blount disease typically progresses as a child grows, especially if the child becomes overweight. While most adolescent cases are a continuation of the infantile form of the disease, the adolescent form can also appear during the teenage years or later, causing an affected individual to have normally formed legs until the outward bowing begins. Like the infantile form of the condition, the adolescent form usually is progressive. Early treatment of both forms of Blount disease typically involves braces, although studies show that bracing is not effective in severe cases. However, in most severe cases, affected individuals will require surgery.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

Being overweight during childhood, early walkers, and certain inherited factors thought to contribute to causing the disease. The condition can affect one or both legs. It is not known why the condition may worsen in some children and be come stable in others.  Treatment of Blount disease depends on the age of the child affected and whether the bowed shin bones are getting worse or have stabilized. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"What are the signs and symptoms of Blount disease? The signs and symptoms of Blount disease usually appear between ages 2 and 5. An affected child typically shows slow and progressive bowing of the lower leg beginning around the time she or he starts walking (i.e., ambulating). The bowing of the legs may occur in both legs, but typically one leg is more severely affected than the other. Because the early symptoms of Blount disease can mimic the more common symptom of bowlegs (genu varum), it might not be recognized until the bowing is more severe. In addition to bowing of the lower legs, Blount disease can also cause internal rotation of the tibia on the femur below the knee, resulting in one or both feet pointing inward while standing or walking. prompt: What is (are) Blue cone monochromatism ?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Blue cone monochromatism is a disorder of the eyes characterized by reduced visual acuity, inability to perceive colors normally (color vision deficiency), involuntary back-and-forth eye movement (nystagmus), increased sensitivity to light (photophobia), and misalignment of the eyes (strabismus). This condition is typically inherited through the X chromosome and nearly always affects males. Treatment typically involves correcting the refractive error with eyeglasses or contact lenses.  Because males have only one X chromosome, a single altered copy of the gene in each cell causes the condition in males. In females (who have two X chromosomes), a mutation would have to occur in both copies of the gene to cause the disorder. If a female inherits one mutated copy, she is called a carrier and can pass on the mutation to her offspring. Carriers usually do not show signs and symptoms of the condition because the other copy of the gene in each cell is functioning normally.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Blue cone monochromatism (BCM) is an infrequently diagnosed genetic retinal condition resulting in reduced vision from early infancy. Color vision is limited to blue and shades of gray, and light seems abnormally bright. It affects around 1 in 100,000 people, with males being affected far more frequently than females, in a ratio of approximately 8:1. BCM is an X-linked disorder, and thus affects mostly males, who have one X chromosome. Males with this condition are missing or have a nonworking version of their opsin genes on the X chromosome inherited from their mother. In some cases, a female can also be affected if she inherits a mutated X chromosome from her mother and a deleted X chromosome from her father.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Blue cone monochromatism is an inherited eye disorder that causes severe color vision reduction (color vision deficiency) and poor sharpness of vision (low visual acuity). People with this condition mistakenly see reds, greens, and (yellow,) as similar colors, when they should be distinct. They also have trouble distinguishing any colors in dim light. Nearly all males with blue cone monochromatism have the sharpness of vision needed to read 20/80 or worse without glasses. Other eye abnormalities are also characteristic of blue cone monochromatism, including involuntary eye movements (nystagmus) and extreme nearsightedness (high myopia).  Color vision depends on cells in the eye called cones, which detect light and color. Humans usually have three types of cones, which detect red (long, or L, wavelengths of light), green (medium, or M, wavelengths), and blue (short, or S, wavelengths). The combination of these three types of cones gives people normal color vision (trichromacy).  People with blue cone monochromatism lack L cones and M cones. They only have S cones, the blue cones. Because they only have one type of cone, these individuals are called monochromats. Blue cone monochromatism and achromatopsia (which is caused by a lack of all three types of cones) are the two types of cone monochromatism. Cone monochromacy is often associated with a condition called rod monochromacy. Rods are another type of cell in the eye; light detection by rods results in vision (sight) without color (black and white). Rod monochromats, who lack cones altogether, only have rods, and therefore see only in black, white, and gray.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Blue cone monochromatism is a condition characterized by a loss of color vision (color blindness) and other vision abnormalities that vary in type and severity. People with this disorder have few, if any, functional long- or middle-wavelength-sensitive (L or M) cones in their eyes.  Consequently, people with blue cone monochromatism rely on  short wavelength-sensitive (S) cones, which perceive blue light, and rods, which perceive light and dark, for their vision. The absence of functioning L and M cones makes it impossible for people with this condition to distinguish some colors (dichromacy) or to see any color at all (achromatopsia). Other common features include reduced sharpness of vision (low visual acuity); small involuntary, back-and-forth eye movements (nystagmus); extreme sensitivity to light (photophobia); involuntary eye movement and bending (torsional pendular nystagmus); and eyes that do not point in the same direction (strabismus).  Some people with blue cone monochromatism also have a progressive version of the disorder, which is associated with deterioration of the light-sensitive tissue lining the back of the eyes (the retina).","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Blue cone monochromatism is a condition that affects vision. It is characterized by partial or complete loss of color vision (cerebral achromatopsia), poor vision from birth (congenital low visual acuity), and increased sensitivity to bright lights (photophobia). Individuals with this condition may also experience involuntary rapid movement of the eyes (nystagmus).  Blue cone monochromatism is the most severe type of X-linked incomplete achromatopsia caused by red-green color vision deficiency gene mutations.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

It usually occurs on the skin and in the gastrointestinal (GI) tract, but can also occur in the liver, spleen, muscles, anywhere in the body. Lesions on the skin tend to be found on the torso and limbs. Symptoms are typically GI bleeding and iron deficiency anemia. Lesions may also leak blood into the tissues, causing swelling and pain. prompt: What is (are) Bobble-head doll syndrome ?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Bobble-head doll syndrome is a movement disorder characterized by forward-backward or side-to-side oscillations of the head at a frequency of 2-3 hertz (Hz). The presence of such oscillations suggest that the affected individual should be imaged (usually with magnetic resonance imaging - MRI scan) to rule out the likely brain abnormalities which are often associated with the syndrome or condition.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Bobble-head doll syndrome (BHDS) is a movement disorder that cause children to repetitively and involuntarily nod the head up and down or rotate the head from side to side about 2-3 times per second. This condition mainly occurs in children and the head movement disappears during sleep, attention or concentration. Other symptoms can include tremor and tics. Most patients also have hydrocephalus (abnormal accumulation of fluid in the brain). A characteristic abnormality of the brain is observed in all patients with this condition (cystic dilation of the third ventricle). Treatment involves the use of shunts (a type of small, flexible drain) and/or fenestration (creation of openings across the thin membrane). Early treatment can prevent permanent brain damage.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Bobble-head doll syndrome is a rare movement disorder that usually affects children. The syndrome was first described in 1966, although tremors in children with brain cysts and hydrocephalus (cerebrospinal fluid buildup in the brain) were noted as far back as 1902. The exact cause of the bobble-head movements is not clear. It is associated with fluid-filled cysts and other types of brain malformations that cause mild to moderate hydrocephalus.  Children with this syndrome usually have a characteristic head movement that varies from a side-to-side \"bobble\" motion to a back-and-forth \"yes-yes\" or side-to-side \"no-no\" motion, or a combination of the two. The movements make the child appear like a bobble-head doll. A few cases report tremors in other parts of the body. People with this syndrome may also have other signs and symptoms of hydrocephalus, including intellectual disability, visual and/or speech impairment. Some people have no other symptoms and no apparent health problems. The age at which the bobble-head movements begin varies from around age 1 to 12 years, but most often occurs between ages 3 and 6. When a brain cyst is the underlying cause, the abnormal head movements almost always appear once the cyst has enlarged. Treatment of human growth hormone deficiency has improved signs and symptoms in one reported case. Surgery with the aim of normalizing cerebrospinal fluid flow (such as insertion of shunt or endoscopic fenestration) has been successful in alleviating the abnormal movements in some cases.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Bobble-head doll syndrome is a very rare neurological disorder characterized by an involuntary head bobbing movement. It typically begins in childhood before the age of five. Episodes of head nodding occur approximately two to three times per second. While the condition is chronic, the head bobbing tends to stop during sleep and concentration. It typically worsens during anxiety or stress. Individuals with bobble-head doll syndrome may also experience a variety of other signs and symptoms, which can include an unsteady gait (ataxia), unusual eye movement (nystagmus), vomiting, irritability, and problems with intellectual development. The underlying cause is not fully known; however, it is thought to be associated with an impairment of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) flow. In some cases, a fluid-filled sac called a cyst may be the cause; cysts can press on the brain and cause CSF to collect. Treatment varies depending on the cause of the condition and the symptoms present in the affected person; however, most individuals benefit from some sort of brain surgery.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Bobble-head doll syndrome (BHDS) is a rare movement disorder which has been associated with cystic lesions or other malformations around or above the third ventricle of the brain. It is characterized by involuntary to-and-fro head movements, usually at a rate of 2 to 3 cycles per second. These movements are associated with anteroposterior (nodding) or rotational (shaking) movement. Signs and symptoms of BHDS progress with age. BHDS is sometimes associated with other neurological symptoms such as tremors, tics, neck stiffness, rigidity, signs of cerebellar dysfunction, hydrocephalus, and intellectual disability. A definitive cause and cure is unknown.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What is (are) BOD syndrome ?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"BOD syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by developmental delay; short stature; and distinctive facial features, including a large head, low frontal hairline, and high-arched or cleft palate. It is named after the surnames of the first people to be diagnosed with the condition and was first identified in 1990. It is thought to be caused by mutations in an as-yet-unidentified gene. Treatment is based on the diagnosed problems in each person. In adults, BOD stands for brachycephaly, ocular hypertelorism, and downslanting palpebral fissures; in children, BOD stands for big brain, obstructed breathing, and developmental delay.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"BOD syndrome is a metabolic condition that is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. People with BOD syndrome have symptoms of both Bartter syndrome and osteogenesis imperfecta.  Bartter syndrome  is a disorder that affects the kidneys. It usually begins before birth and disrupts normal kidney function. The signs and symptoms of Bartter syndrome can include unusually large amounts of urine, thirst and dehydration, constipation, growth delay, and a loss of minerals such as potassium, calcium, and sodium in the urine. There are several different types of Bartter syndrome; the type that occurs with BOD syndrome is called type III or classic Bartter syndrome.  Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) is a connective tissue disorder that primarily affects the bones. People with OI have bones that break easily, often from mild trauma or without an apparent cause. Other signs and symptoms that can occur with OI include blue sclerae (the whites of the eyes have a blue tint), hearing loss, a triangular face shape, loose joints and poor muscle tone, and short stature. There are several types of OI varying from mild to severe; the type that occurs with BOD syndrome is mild.  People with BOD syndrome inherit characteristics of both Bartter syndrome and osteogenesis imperfecta. They have a tendency for bone fractures caused by osteoporosis, which is a loss of minerals from the bones. They also have an increased risk of developing kidney stones.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"\"BOD\" stands for \"bent-bone, oligosyndactyly, and distinctive face,\" a pattern of birth defects seen in babies who have a rare form of short-rib thoracic dysplasia with polydactyly called short-rib polydactyly syndrome (SRPS) type III. People with BOD syndrome have a small, underdeveloped chest which causes life-threatening breathing problems.  Additional features of BOD syndrome include limbs that are short and bowed; hands and feet where some of the fingers and toes are joined (syndactyly); and distinctive facial features, which may include a prominent forehead, wide-set eyes (hypertelorism), a depressed nasal bridge, and small chin (micrognathia). Ovarian cysts can be a feature of the condition in females.  The signs and symptoms of BOD syndrome overlap with those of other types of SRPS. A unique complication of BOD syndrome is that affected individuals who survive infancy often develop nephronophthisis, a kidney disease that causes progressive kidney failure and death in adolescence.  Most individuals with BOD syndrome survive beyond one year, but very few live to reach adulthood.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"BOD syndrome is an eye disease that mainly affects the myope, that is, the person with myopia - \"nearsightedness\". It consists of three components: The B - \"Blepharospasm\": this is an involuntary \"blinking\" of the eye or \"dancing of the eye lash\". The O - \"Oculogyric crisis\": eyes looking to one particular side or upwards for no particular reason. The D - \"Dystonia\": is an abnormal movement of the face, neck and shoulders. This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion and one gene has been found - GNAL gene - but only in one family. Treatment options are limited and mainly consists of medication to reduce the eye twitching and muscle spasms. Botulinum toxin injections may be helpful.more...","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Book syndrome (BS) is a disorder that is characterized by an elongated, \"bony\" face with midface retrusion (undergrowth of the upper face) and malar hypoplasia (absent cheekbones). The jaws are prominent with little to no chin. The head is larger than normal with a prominent forehead and craniosynostosis (premature fusing of the skull bones). Ears may be overfolded or have an overfolded superior helix. Additional signs and symptoms include distinct nose, tall and broad hands with tapering fingers, severe myopia (nearsightedness), and hearing loss. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Borjeson-Forssman-Lehmann syndrome (BFLS) is a rare genetic condition characterized by distinctive signs and symptoms that affect several body systems. This syndrome is characterized by intellectual disability, distinctive facial features, and obesity beginning in early childhood. Intellectual disability associated with BFLS may range from mild to severe. Behavioral abnormalities may occur, as well, including autism spectrum behaviors and obsession with food. In early childhood, individuals with this syndrome may be overweight; however, they develop an appearance characterized by thin arms and legs and excess fat deposits on the upper body and upper back (buffalo hump) in adolescence or early adulthood. Facial features characteristic of BFLS include drooping eyelids (ptosis), deep-set eyes, narrow eyelid openings (palpebral fissures), a long face, a prominent nose, a square jaw, and large ears that stick out from the head.  Males with BFLS have distinctive bumps (nodules) on their testes that are related to the same genetic mutation that causes the other signs and symptoms of this condition. Most males with BFLS have small testes and abnormally low levels of testosterone. Low levels of testosterone in affected males are associated with impaired development of the genitalia, changes (mosaicism) in some cells affecting the number or structure of the X chromosomes, and intellectual disability.  Additional features of BFLS include low muscle tone (hypotonia); weak muscle strength; floppiness of joints; restricted movement of some joints; flexion contractures of the hand; and other joint problems. Some individuals with BFLS experience recurrent seizures as well as abnormalities in brain development. Some affected individuals may have an extra skin fold across the palm. In some individuals, the fingers are fused together and the thumbs are in an unusual position and may be fixed with the palm towards the back of the hand (pronated thumb). Dental problems are common and may include an extra number of small teeth (supernumerary natal teeth), umbrella-shaped molars, small lower jaw, widely spaced teeth, missing teeth, and teeth that protrude slightly from the mouth. Secondary sexual features are usually normal among affected females.  BFLS is most often diagnosed in males. In rare cases, females who have a mutation in the PHF6 gene can be affected. Affected females have mild to severe intellectual disability and may have additional signs and symptoms of this syndrome.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What is (are) Brachydactyly type B ?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Brachydactyly type B is a condition that affects the development of bones in the fingers and toes. This condition causes the long bones of the fingers (phalanges) to be abnormally short, with the smaller bones that make up the fingernails (distal hypoplasia) most severely affected. As a result of abnormal nail bone development, individuals with brachydactyly type B have shortened, and sometimes missing, fingernails. The middle fingers and toes can also be affected by short phalanges and shortened fingernails or toenails. The changes seen in the fingers and toes occur early in fetal development and can be described in prenatal ultrasound imaging.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Brachydactyly is a general term referring to abnormal shortness of the fingers and/or toes due to unusually short bones (phalanges or metacarpals/metatarsals). Brachydactyly type B is characterized by a short terminal phalanx in all of the fingers and toes. Nails of the fingers and sometimes the toes are absent or hypoplastic. Other hand abnormalities such as syndactyly (webbing or fusing) of the fingers have been described. It is an autosomal dominant disorder and has been associated with mutations in the ROR2 gene. It is estimated to occur in 1/100,000 individuals.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Brachydactyly type B (BDB) is a malformation of the fingers and toes. This condition hampers the normal growth (development) of the fingers. Underdevelopment or abnormal shortness (brachydactyly) most severely affects the last finger bones (distal phalanges), and this causes unusual nails and skin fold. The last bones of the thumb and big toe are usually involved as well. In severe cases, the bones that make up the joints of the fingers (phalangeal joints) are missing and fingernails are completely absent. People with BDB sometimes have reduced numbers of digits (oligodactyly) or abnormally short thumbs (brachymetacarpalia) and toes (brachymetatarsalia). Most affected people don't have any medical problems related to this condition and have normal intelligence.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Brachydactyly type B is an abnormality of hand development that can affect both the bones (skeletal brachydactyly) and the soft parts of the hand, including the skin and nails (nonskeletal brachydactyly). This condition is characterized by short, wide fingers and toes, and abnormal or missing fingernails and toenails (nail hypoplasia). Brachydactyly type B also typically causes underdevelopment of multiple bones in the fingers and toes. In particular, the middle bone (second phalanx) and end bone (distal phalanx) of the fingers and toes are either shortened or absent. This results in shortened extremities and can cause the fingers and toes to look squared, bulbous, or stubby. Other signs and symptoms of this condition may include webbing between the first and second toes (syndactyly), reduced movement (flexion) in the fingers, and enlarged knuckles.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Brachydactyly type B is a condition that causes abnormalities of the bones in the fingers and toes. Brachydactyly type B is characterized by short or missing bones in the distal phalanges, which are the fingers and toes farthest from the hand or foot. The nails of the fingers and toes may also be abnormal or missing. The middle sections of the fingers (called middle phalanges) may be shortened, and the joints in the middle and the end segments of the fingers may be fused or missing. In some people with brachydactyly type B, all of the fingers are affected, while in others only a few fingers show abnormalities.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"What are the signs and symptoms of Brachydactyly type B? All of the fingers (digits II through V) on both hands are affected by finger malformation. The thumb may be affected or unaffected by malformation. The distal and the middle phalanges are hypoplastic or absent in most fingers. The proximal phalanx is relatively long and wide. The metacarpals are relatively long and wide. Nail aplasia or hypoplasia is present in the fingers; in some cases also the thumbs lack nails. Abnormalities of the thumb are inconsistent; some affected individuals have hypoplastic and narrowed thumbs, and others have aplasia of the phalanx and of the nail. All affected individuals have a short and broad thumb. Carpal bones LABC (lunate, triquetral, and pisiform) and LM (lunar and magnum) are absent. The most striking and consistent feature of this type of brachydactyly is the presence of aplasia or hypoplasia of the lateral (ulnar), and frequently also of the medial (radial), phalanges in the second through fifth fingers. This is associated with nail aplasia/hypoplasia on the respective fingers. Some textbooks include aplasia or hypoplasia of the distal phalanx of the thumb as a characteristic feature as well. The U.S. National Library of Medicine's MedlinePlus Encyclopedia webpage on brachydactyly offers drawings that show major types of brachydactyly. The signs and symptoms described in association with Brachydactyly type B were obtained from the National Human Genome Research Institute's Web site.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

The thumb may be abnormally short, and there may be abnormal outward curvature of the ring finger (clinodactyly). Toes are generally less affected than fingers, though they may also be shorter than usual.  In people with BDC, some of the finger and toe bones are abnormally long or short. In particular, the outermost (distal) bones of the index finger and little finger may be unusually long. prompt: What is (are) essential thrombocythemia ?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Essential thrombocythemia (ET) is a myeloproliferative neoplasm (MPN). MPNs are a group of slow-growing blood cancers in which the bone marrow makes too many of one or more types of blood cells. In ET, the bone marrow produces too many platelets. Platelets are blood cells that help the blood to clot.    In most cases, having too many platelets does not cause problems. However, eating aspirin or other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) can cause the platelets to not work properly, which may lead to bleeding problems. Fewer than 1 in 5 people with ET have signs or symptoms of the disease. These may include the following: Overgrowth of blood vessels under the skin, which look like red dots or lines. A feeling of burning or painful tingling in the hands or feet. A headache. Vision problems. Dizziness. Weakness. Uncommon signs and symptoms of ET include blood clots and bleeding, leukemia, and myelofibrosis. MPNs can become acute leukemia, usually after many years.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"length","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Key Points
                    - Essential thrombocythemia is a disease in which too many platelets are made in the blood.    - Most patients with essential thrombocythemia have no symptoms.    - A blood sample is checked to diagnose essential thrombocythemia.    - Treatment for essential thrombocythemia may include         - High-dose aspirin     -  Plateletpheresis     -  Interferon alfa        - Tests that examine bone marrow are used to diagnose essential thrombocythemia.    - Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.         - Whether bleeding, clotting, or other symptoms occur         - The age of the patient        -  Smoking        -  JAK2 mutation
                
                
                    Essential thrombocythemia is a disease in which too many platelets are made in the blood.
                    Essential thrombocythemia (ET) is a rare blood cancer in which too many platelets are made in the bone marrow. Normally, the number of platelets made in the bone marrow is determined by the body?s need to replace platelets that are lost by bleeding or in tissues where there is injury or a healing wound. In ET, however, high numbers of platelets are made even when they are not needed. Very high numbers of platelets in the blood may cause excessive bleeding or the formation of blood clots. A high number of platelets can also lead to increased numbers of white blood cells and red blood cells.     ET is one of several types of myeloproliferative neoplasms. In patients with myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPNs), part of the bone marrow makes too many red blood cells, white blood cells, or platelets. See the following PDQ summaries for more information about other types of MPNs:         -  Polycythemia Vera and Other Myeloproliferative Neoplasms Treatment     -  Myeloproliferative Neoplasms Treatment: Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia, Polycythemia Vera, Essential Thrombocythemia, and Myelofibrosis
                
                
                    Most patients with essential thrombocythemia have no symptoms.
                   Most patients with ET do not have symptoms. Rarely, patients with ET have a headache or pain, tingling, or numbness in the hands or feet. These symptoms result from too many platelets in the blood. Very high numbers of platelets may also cause excessive bleeding or the formation of blood clots. Some patients with ET have both bleeding and clotting problems.
                
                
                    A blood sample is checked to diagnose essential thrombocythemia.
                    A diagnosis of ET is made only when the platelet count is very high. If less than 1 million platelets per microliter of blood are found, ET is not diagnosed. In addition, other causes of high numbers of platelets, such as an infection, a chronic inflammatory disease, a type of cancer that spreads to the bone marrow, iron-deficiency anemia, or other bone marrow diseases, must be ruled out. Because signs and symptoms of some other diseases and infections are the same as those of ET, careful diagnosis is important. The following tests may be used to screen for ET:          -   Complete blood count with differential : A procedure in which a sample of blood is drawn and the number of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets are counted. The blood sample may also be checked for other factors, such as the percentage of blood made up of red blood cells (hematocrit), the amount of hemoglobin (the protein that carries oxygen) in the red blood cells, and the size and shape of the red blood cells. A differential white blood cell count is also done to count and see the different types of white blood cells. The complete blood count is usually done in the doctor?s office.    -   Blood chemistry studies : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances, such as electrolytes (the salts and minerals, such as sodium and potassium, in your blood that affect how your body functions), creatinine (the chemical waste product that is removed by the kidneys) and urea nitrogen (the end product of protein metabolism, which is removed by the kidneys), and liver enzymes (proteins that speed chemical reactions in the body) in the blood. The way these substances are found in the blood may give the doctor clues about how well certain organs, such as the liver and kidneys, are working.    -  Blood clotting studies : Procedures to measure the time it takes for blood to clot and the amount of clotting factors the blood has.
                
                
                    Treatment for essential thrombocythemia may include

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is a condition characterized by the development of hundreds to thousands of small growths called polyps in the colon and rectum during the second or third decade of life. In many people, colorectal cancer develops by age 40 if the colon is not removed. Another feature of classic FAP is a growth in the eye called a congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE). Other types of growths that have been reported in people with FAP include small bumps called osteomas that develop on or under the bones of the face, dental abnormalities, and cysts under the skin (epidermoid cysts).  Variants of FAP include Gardner syndrome, which is associated with epidermoid cysts, osteomas, and other tumors as well as the human version of a hereditary condition in the Irish demonstrating extreme polyposis.  Cancer in the upper gastrointestinal (GI) tract also occurs in familial adenomatous polyposis, such as small growths called duodenal and peri-ampullary adenomas that develop in the second part of the small intestine (duodenum). People with FAP are also at risk of stomach polyps and desmoid-type fibromas (noncancerous connective tissue growths). Less commonly, FAP is associated with an increased risk of other types of tumors that may occur outside the GI tract, such as thyroid cancer, brain cancer (medulloblastoma), liver cancer, and cancers of the bile ducts (cholangiocarcinoma).  Individuals who develop hundreds or thousands of polyps in early adulthood due to FAP are said to have \"classic\" FAP. A similar condition with fewer polyps (fewer than 100) is called attenuated familial adenomatous polyposis (AFAP). AFAP is often associated with later onset of polyps and a slower progression to colon cancer.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What are the genetic changes related to familial adenomatous polyposis ?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Mutations in the APC gene cause FAP and its variants. The APC gene provides instructions for making a protein that is involved in several important processes including cell division and adhesion, and the transmission of signals in several key signaling pathways, most notably the Wnt signaling pathway. Wnt signaling is evolutionarily conserved across animal species and is essential for normal development before birth. After birth, it is important for the renewal of cells within the intestine and other organs, and the repair of tissues following injury. The APC protein contributes to the regulation of a protein called beta-catenin, which is an essential component of Wnt signaling. The APC protein helps to maintain appropriate levels of beta-catenin (also known as CTNNB1) within cells. When Wnt signaling begins, beta-catenin can enter the nucleus, the compartment that contains the cell's DNA. Beta-catenin binds to specific proteins and together they activate or enhance the activity of certain genes. When Wnt signaling stops, beta-catenin leaves the nucleus and is rapidly degraded (broken down).  Mutations in the APC gene lead to a loss of regulation of beta-catenin, which results in the accumulation of beta-catenin within the cell. Beta-catenin enters the nucleus inappropriately and activates genes that influence cell growth, including the genes involved in the growth of polyps and cancer.  In people with attenuated familial adenomatous polyposis, polyps usually begin to develop in the teenage years. In this condition, fewer than 100 polyps appear in the large intestine. Mutations that cause this condition are typically found at either end of the APC gene. These mutations preserve some of the normal function of the APC protein, which is thought to reduce the number of polyps in affected people.  In FAP, polyps usually begin to develop in late childhood or the teenage years. In FAP, more than 100 polyps typically appear in the large intestine, and some people have thousands of polyps. Mutations that cause FAP are most often found in the central region of the APC gene. These mutations result in a nonfunctional APC protein.  MUTYH-associated polyposis is caused by MUTYH gene mutations that are inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means that people with the condition inherit two mutated copies of the gene, one from each parent. The MUTYH gene provides instructions for making a protein called MYH glycosylase, which acts in DNA repair. This protein removes DNA damage that would otherwise cause mutations in a gene called KRAS and the APC gene. Mutations in KRAS and the APC gene are associated with multiple colorectal adenomas and the cancer predisposition characteristic of FAP. When both copies of the MUTYH gene are mutated, DNA repair is impaired, which leads to the formation of multiple adenomas and an increased risk of cancer. (For more information about autosomal recessive inheritance, see the MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia.)  In some cases, no genetic cause of polyposis can be identified. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The APC gene provides instructions for making a protein that plays an important role in several cellular processes, including cell growth and division. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The surgical treatment of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is highly individualized. These disorders are characterized by progressive damage to nerves of the peripheral nervous system (the network of nerves beyond the brain and spinal cord). Depending on the type of HSAN, loss of sensory nerve function interferes with the perception of pain and temperature. The autonomic nerves that are affected in these conditions regulate certain involuntary body functions such as blood pressure, breathing, and digestion. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":1,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"The term familial dysautonomia describes a group of signs and symptoms resulting from the abnormal development and degeneration of certain nerve cells. Many of the characteristic features of familial dysautonomia reflect the role of these nerves in controlling involuntary body functions, such as regulating blood pressure, body temperature, and digestion.  Familial dysautonomia results from mutations in the IKBKAP gene. This gene provides instructions for making a protein called IKAP, which is thought to be involved in the control of gene activity and plays a role in nerve cells. Most of the nerve cells affected in familial dysautonomia are located outside of the brain and spinal cord (these cells are part of the peripheral nervous system). They are important for relaying signals between the central nervous system and the rest of the body.  The most common IKBKAP gene mutation results in a form of the gene called the \"tissue-specific mutation\" because it impairs production of functional IKAP protein in some tissues more than others. Researchers believe that low levels of IKAP protein impair the development and survival of certain peripheral nerve cells. The IKBKAP gene mutations that cause familial dysautonomia can significantly reduce production of the IKAP protein. This reduction in protein is particularly severe in nervous system tissue. completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Familial encephalopathy with neuroserpin inclusion bodies (FENIB) is a rare inherited brain disease. This condition is a type of dementia, and affected individuals experience progressive intellectual decline until they become severely demented. Related symptoms may include seizures, confusion, weakness, and problems with movement, speech, or swallowing.  FENIB is caused by mutations in the SERPINI1 gene. Neuroserpin helps to regulate (inhibit) the activity of molecules called serine proteases, which perform many vital functions in the body. Serine proteases are involved in processes such as breaking down proteins and fighting infection. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Familial encephalopathy with neuroserpin inclusion bodies is an inherited brain disorder which often causes dementia.  Symptoms are typically limited to impaired thinking and memory. Individuals with this condition may have difficulty concentrating, impaired judgment, and personality changes. Over time these problems may worsen to become severe dementia. In rare cases seizures or migraine episodes can occur.  Familial encephalopathy with neuroserpin inclusion bodies is caused by a change (mutation) in the SERPINI1 gene. This gene provides instructions for making a protein called neuroserpin, which is found primarily in nerve cells (neurons) in the brain. Neuroserpin protects neurons from damage and plays an important role in the development of the nervous system, especially in the formation of neural networks by promoting the growth of new projections from neurons (axons).  The altered neuroserpin protein may fold abnormally and be poorly soluble, resulting in poor transport within neurons and accumulation within the endoplasmic reticulum (ER). The ER is the first step in the secretory pathway of the cell, a pathway used by cells to transport newly synthesized proteins where they are needed. Bottlenecks and transport failure in the secretory pathway resulting from accumulation of abnormally folded proteins have been implicated in several regions of the brain where cell death occurs in various diseases associated with dementia; however, it is not yet known why certain neurons are vulnerable to dysfunction and death in familial encephalopathy with neuroserpin inclusion bodies.  The name of this condition refers to abnormal structures called inclusion bodies, which are found in certain brain cells (neurons) of people with familial encephalopathy with neuroserpin inclusion bodies. These structures are made up of neuroserpin molecules whose structure has been altered by the SERPINI1 gene mutation.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":3,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Familial encephalopathy with neuroserpin inclusion bodies (FENIB) is a rare, genetic brain disease caused by a mutation in the gene called neuroserpin (SERPINI1).  The SERPINI1 gene provides instructions for making a protein called neuroserpin. Neuroserpin is made and used (expressed) in the nervous system, which consists of the brain and spinal cord. Neuroserpin is found in brain structures involved in memory and in areas of the brain that control movement. However, the function of neuroserpin in the nervous system is unknown.  Neuroserpin acts as an inhibitor, which is a type of protein that regulates the activity of other proteins. Specifically, neuroserpin inhibits proteins called serine proteases, which perform a variety of functions in the body, including digestion, blood clotting, and the immune response.  The genetic changes in FENIB replace one building block (amino acid) in neuroserpin with a different amino acid.  The resulting abnormal neuroserpin protein undergoes a conformational change, which is a change in the shape of the protein. This causes individual neuroserpin molecules to stick to one another and form long chains called polymers. The polymers accumulate in specialized structures (inclusion bodies) inside cells called neurons, which transmit nerve impulses. The accumulation of neuroserpin polymers in neurons damages or kills cells in parts of the brain involved in movement and memory. This damage results in the dementia and movement problems characteristic of FENIB. The formation of neuroserpin polymers impairs the ability of neuroserpin to inhibit serine proteases, which may contribute to the disease process.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":4,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Familial encephalopathy with neuroserpin inclusion bodies (FENIB) is a disorder characterized by progressive problems with thinking and memory that tend to worsen over a period of 5 to 15 years. The signs and symptoms of FENIB vary, depending on the age of onset of the disorder. People with early-adult onset FENIB experience mild to moderate cognitive decline. People with younger onset FENIB typically experience severe cognitive decline, and dementia develops within approximately 5 years after the onset of the condition. In people with later onset FENIB, mild cognitive decline does not seem to progress to dementia. Some people with later onset FENIB may also develop seizures, which begin as episodes of loss of awareness followed by convulsions. Episodes of loss of awareness accompanied by convulsions are also referred to as tonic-clonic seizures. Over time, additional signs and symptoms may develop, such as mood disorders, temporary episodes of altered awareness (transient attacks of loss of consciousness and confusion) or recurrent episodes of unconsciousness with uncontrollable shaking (epilepsy).  Neuroserpin is a protein that helps regulate the activity of a molecule involved in the destruction of cells and tissues (protease). Neuroserpin specifically regulates a protease called tissue-type plasminogen activator (tPA), which is produced in the long extensions of nerve cells (neurons) and secreted into synapses, the specialized connections between neurons. tPA regulates processes involved in brain development and nerve cell signaling (neuronal signaling) by breaking large proteins called extracellular matrix proteins into smaller pieces. {"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"How might familial erythrocytosis be treated? Familial erythrocytosis is sometimes called \"benign erythrocytosis\" because it typically does not cause serious problems. Erythrocytosis, however, can thicken the blood, causing it to flow less easily. If blood does not flow well through the small vessels in the body, it can cause headaches, dizziness, or a group of symptoms called erythromelalgia that involves redness, heat, and pain in the hands and feet. The thickness of the blood may also increase the risk of developing a blood clot (thrombus), which could lead to a life-threatening heart attack or stroke with serious injury or death. Additional medical problems caused by erythrocytosis are rare, but they may be serious. For example, an abnormally high number of red blood cells can cause a decrease in the amount of oxygen that reaches delicate areas in the brain and other organs, and certain loss-of-function mutations in the genes for oxygen sensing cause decreases in hormone levels that regulate oxygen in the airways so it is hard for oxygen to travel from the lungs to the rest of the body. Thus, even though the red blood cell count is abnormally high, affected individuals can have episodes where the blood is not circulating well, causing fainting or breathing difficulties. It is important to closely follow affected family members for their entire lives. Studies are being done to determine whether certain types of familial erythrocytosis have similar health risks to the more common acquired erythrocytosis called polycythemia vera (PV). The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has approved the use of a class of medications called JAK inhibitors to treat PV. JAK inhibitors work by targeting the JAK2 protein inside the body's cells. This protein plays an important role in the development of blood stem cells into red blood cells, white blood cells, or platelets. A genetic change known as the JAK2 V617F mutation is found in nearly all people with PV, and studies are underway to evaluate the efficacy of JAK inhibitors to treat PV with this mutation and the high red blood cell counts seen in erythrocytosis. In the past, the treatment of familial erythrocytosis has been primarily focused on removing excess red blood cells through therapeutic phlebotomy (phelbow-theh-knee). Because red blood cells are responsible for carrying oxygen around the body, blood is replaced with fluid (saline) to keep the total amount of blood in the body the same as it was before the phlebotomy.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

{"finish_reason":"stop","index":2,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Summary : International health is a field of health care, usually with a public health emphasis, dealing with health across regional or national boundaries. Aspects of the natural environment such as soil and rock type, climate and water sources can influence disease patterns. Factors in the human social environment such as poverty, education and employment can influence disease incidence and prevalence. The current Ebola epidemic, which is widespread in West Africa but not yet a significant concern in other nations, also illustrates regional and global concerns in international health.    Globalization affects international health. Goods, services, information, investments, and people are moving more freely across borders. Due to increased interdependence worldwide, health concerns of one region may affect the health and well-being of people in other regions.    Patterns of disease in a specific region can influence the pattern of disease in another due to migration and travel. Patterns of disease among recent immigrants from a certain region may reflect those patterns of the region of origin. completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Interstitial cystitis, also called painful bladder syndrome, is an uncomfortable bladder syndrome that afflicts millions. Despite its popularity - it affects far more women than men - not much is known about its exact cause. No bacteria or other causes have been found. Some researchers say it may be an autoimmune disease, others say it may be allergies or a bug not found by other tests.    It takes up to six weeks of medication for a patient to know if it works, so most patients need to cooperate with the doctors. Pain is the main complaint - a burning pain in the bladder and hypo-gastric areas and pain upon penetration. This accompanies other symptoms: urinary urgency and frequency; daytime and nighttime frequency; nocturia; sensation of bladder being full; dyspareunia; and urethral pain and burning. Physical exams usually appear normal, so IC is hard to diagnose.    Treatment usually involves oral medications, mostly pentosan polysulfate sodium. It is successful in 32% of IC patients, in about six weeks. If successful, longer use improves results. A host of other medications are used, and several infusion medicines are being studied. All require a prescription. Behavioral therapy, physical therapy, or other types of therapy may also be recommended. In some cases, an examination with a cystoscope is performed, which allows visualization of the inside of the bladder and urethra. Bone scans, ultrasound exams, and nerve tests are other possible diagnostic tools.    NIH: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

prompt: What is (are) Interstitial Lung Diseases ?
completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Interstitial lung diseases (ILDs) are a group of diseases that affect the tissue and space around the air sacs of the lungs. The tissue around the air sacs of your lungs is called interstitium. It supports the air sacs and helps them expand and contract as you breathe.    In ILDs the interstitium can become inflamed and swollen. If this happens over a long period it can become permanently scarred. This scarring is also called fibrosis. The scarring makes it difficult for oxygen to pass through the walls of the air sacs into the bloodstream. This results in less oxygen getting to the body.    Some types of ILD start suddenly, while others begin slowly. Most types get worse over time. Scleroderma, dermatomyositis, rheumatoid arthritis, and other autoimmune diseases can cause ILD. Researchers believe most types of ILD may be autoimmune diseases. Other causes of ILD are or were in the scaring of the lung tissues through pollution of the environment, lung cancer treatment, drug treatment and injuries.    Symptoms of ILDs include shortness of breath and a dry cough. Medicines and sometimes oxygen therapy and rehabilitation help relieve the symptoms of ILDs.    NIH: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

They tell cells which proteins to make and when to make them. With XXY syndrome, a person is born with an extra copy of the X chromosome in each of his cells. completions: {"finish_reason":"stop","index":0,"logprobs":null,"message":{"content":"Lewy body disease is a disorder of abnormal protein deposits inside nerve cells that are associated with Parkinson's disease and Alzheimer's disease. These protein deposits, which are known as Lewy bodies (named after the scientist who first described them) and Lewy neurites, are made of alpha-synuclein protein. Lewy bodies and Lewy neurites spread progressively throughout the brain, leading to dementia and eventual death.  Lewy body disease is considered a spectrum disorder that is often referred to as Lewy body dementias. Lewy body dementia develops when abnormal deposits damage the brain's nerve cells and disrupt the normal functioning of the brain's chemical messengers involved in thinking, memory and movement. The first symptoms of the disorder are often difficulties with problem-solving, memory, attention, and mood. People with dementia with Lewy bodies also develop visual hallucinations, tremors and rigidity, and slow movements. Individuals with dementia with Lewy bodies usually begin to show movement difficulties and cognitive changes within a year of each other.  In Parkinson's disease, the death of nerve cells in the part of the brain called the substantia nigra (midbrain) begins earlier than in other brain regions, resulting in a shortage of the important brain chemical dopamine. As a result, people with Parkinson's disease develop movement problems such as muscle stiffness, tremor, sound freezing (akinesia), poor balance, and slow movement. When people with Parkinson's disease later experience severe dementia, they are diagnosed with Parkinson's disease dementia.  Studies using brain imaging have found differences between Parkinson's disease dementia and dementia with Lewy bodies, although the two disorders share many features and can only definitively be distinguished by examining brain tissue after death.  People who have mostly movement problems caused by the loss of dopamine nerve cells (such as Parkinson's disease) usually have symptoms later. When brain cell loss is primarily related to a shortage of acetylcholine (another brain chemical that transmits messages between nerve cells) and affects the cerebral cortex (the part of the brain responsible for memory, attention to task, language, and perception) sooner, a person is more likely to develop dementia in the earlier stages of the disease.","refusal":null,"role":"assistant","annotations":[],"audio":null,"function_call":null,"tool_calls":null}}

                    The lungs are a pair of cone-shaped breathing organs inside the chest. The lungs are made of spongy tissue and are surrounded by a membrane called the pleura.    When you breathe, air moves through the nose, into the trachea, which divides into the right and left bronchus. Cancer cells begin to grow within the lung in these airways, alveoli, or the pleura and may spread through the lymph system or the bloodstream to other parts of the body.    Lung cancer may affect one or both lungs, damage the airways, and make it hard to breathe. Treatment for lung cancer may harm healthy lung tissue. When a diagnosis of lung cancer is made, the patient and doctor should decide on treatment together. Doctors and patients weigh the risks of having treatment, such as surgery, radiation, and/or chemotherapy that may damage healthy lung tissue, versus the chance it can help the patient and how the patient may feel during and after treatment. An example of memory is when a person sees a certain type of dog, remembers seeing a person that owns a dog that matches the same type, and goes to the person in need of assistance. Short-term memory (STM) is the capacity for holding, but not manipulating, a small amount of information in mind in an active, readily available state for a short period of time.
